commit_message:
Swarm: Map master address to api_address based on TLS

api_address is a API address instead of master node's IP address.
This patch fix it by adding a new OutputMapping, it will help to handle
the mapping from master address to api_address.

Also test cases added.

Closes-Bug: #1514311
Change-Id: I47baf92dd466150adbd75746d0cb804d108f7d5f

subject: Fix fedora-minimal kernel-install on older platforms
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-27 04:41:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/87afd0c207ead8e9ff1c6fdd16fdd0f52b16f294', 'message': "Fix fedora-minimal kernel-install on older platforms

fedora-minimal fails to build on Ubuntu Trusty due do being unable to
find the initrd (see Id4c04d7ae20068643df34d2fa31068e8a917a52d).

This is a rather obscure problem that comes from the intersection of
several things.

The first thing to note is that the post-install scripts of the
kernel-core package use kernel-install [1].  For whatever reason, this
installs the kernel to /boot/MACHINE-ID/KERNEL-VERSION

MACHINE-ID comes from /etc/machine-id; a UUID that should have been
created by the systemd post-inst scripts with systemd-machine-id-setup
[2].

The chroot environment provided for root.d elements has no kernel
file-systems like /proc or /dev mounted.  This is where differences in
the base-system come into play -- on more recent systems that
implement getrandom() systemd does not need /dev/urandom to generate
the machine-id [3]; we get a value and /etc/machine-id is populated.

On older platforms (Trusty), systemd-machine-id-setup fails (unable to
access /dev/urandom) and we end up with a blank /etc/machine-id.  This
ends up making kernel-install (the script) fail during yum's
installation of kernel-core, which means the initrd is not installed
correctly.

We end up bailing out in fedora-minimal/install.d/99-ramdisk, where we
try to put the installed ramdisk in /boot for the later grub install
scripts to find.

The solution here is to mount the standard kernel file-systems within
the chroot before we try installing.

[1] http://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/kernel-install.html
[2] http://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/systemd-machine-id-setup.html
[3] https://github.com/systemd/systemd/blob/master/src/basic/random-util.c

Change-Id: Ibcce35da928f64e6a719b070bcc833346ee7ee92
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-10-28 00:00:59.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/c91677347cd06452fbec233f6062769e07be648b', 'message': "Fix fedora-minimal kernel-install on older platforms

fedora-minimal fails to build on Ubuntu Trusty due do being unable to
find the initrd (see Id4c04d7ae20068643df34d2fa31068e8a917a52d).

several things.

kernel-core package use kernel-install [1].  For whatever reason, this
installs the kernel to /boot/MACHINE-ID/KERNEL-VERSION

MACHINE-ID comes from /etc/machine-id; a UUID that should have been
created by the systemd post-inst scripts with systemd-machine-id-setup
[2].

The chroot environment provided for root.d elements has no kernel
file-systems like /proc or /dev mounted.  This is where differences in
the base-system come into play -- on more recent systems that
implement getrandom() systemd does not need /dev/urandom to generate
the machine-id [3]; we get a value and /etc/machine-id is populated.

On older platforms (Trusty), systemd-machine-id-setup fails (unable to
access /dev/urandom) and we end up with a blank /etc/machine-id.  This
ends up making kernel-install (the script) fail during yum's
installation of kernel-core, which means the initrd is not installed
correctly.

We end up bailing out in fedora-minimal/install.d/99-ramdisk, where we
try to put the installed ramdisk in /boot for the later grub install
scripts to find.

The solution here is to mount the standard kernel file-systems within
the chroot before we try installing.

[1] http://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/kernel-install.html
[2] http://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/systemd-machine-id-setup.html
[3] https://github.com/systemd/systemd/blob/master/src/basic/random-util.c

the base-system come into play -- on more recent systems that
implement getrandom() systemd does not need /dev/urandom to generate
the machine-id [3]; we get a value and /etc/machine-id is populated.

On older platforms (Trusty), systemd-machine-id-setup fails (unable to
access /dev/urandom) and we end up with a blank /etc/machine-id.  This
ends up making kernel-install (the script) fail during yum's
installation of kernel-core, which means the initrd is not installed
correctly.

We end up bailing out in fedora-minimal/install.d/99-ramdisk, where we
try to put the installed ramdisk in /boot for the later grub install
scripts to find.

The solution here is to mount the standard kernel file-systems within
the chroot before we try installing.

[1] http://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/kernel-install.html
[2] http://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/systemd-machine-id-setup.html
[3] https://github.com/systemd/systemd/blob/master/src/basic/random-util.c

Change-Id: Ibcce35da928f64e6a719b070bcc833346ee7ee92
"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2015-11-03 19:25:06.000000000', 'files': ['elements/yum-minimal/root.d/08-yum-chroot'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/f307bb4d8b08e1050955c7756d1cea92bdd5ff56', 'message': "Fix fedora-minimal kernel-install on older platforms

fedora-minimal fails to build on Ubuntu Trusty due do being unable to
find the initrd (see Id4c04d7ae20068643df34d2fa31068e8a917a52d).

This is a rather obscure problem that comes from the intersection of
several things.

The first thing to note is that the post-install scripts of the
kernel-core package use kernel-install [1].  For whatever reason, this
installs the kernel to /boot/MACHINE-ID/KERNEL-VERSION

MACHINE-ID comes from /etc/machine-id; a UUID that should have been
created by the systemd post-inst scripts with systemd-machine-id-setup
[2].

The chroot environment provided for root.d elements has no kernel
file-systems like /proc or /dev mounted.  This is where differences in
the base-system come into play -- on more recent systems that
implement getrandom() systemd does not need /dev/urandom to generate
the machine-id [3]; we get a value and /etc/machine-id is populated.

On older platforms (Trusty), systemd-machine-id-setup fails (unable to
access /dev/urandom) and we end up with a blank /etc/machine-id.  This
ends up making kernel-install (the script) fail during yum's
installation of kernel-core, which means the initrd is not installed
correctly.

We end up bailing out in fedora-minimal/install.d/99-ramdisk, where we
try to put the installed ramdisk in /boot for the later grub install
scripts to find.

The solution here is to mount the standard kernel file-systems within
the chroot before we try installing.

[1] http://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/kernel-install.html
[2] http://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/systemd-machine-id-setup.html
[3] https://github.com/systemd/systemd/blob/master/src/basic/random-util.c

Change-Id: Ibcce35da928f64e6a719b070bcc833346ee7ee92

commit_message:
Fix fedora-minimal kernel-install on older platforms

fedora-minimal fails to build on Ubuntu Trusty due do being unable to
find the initrd (see Id4c04d7ae20068643df34d2fa31068e8a917a52d).

This is a rather obscure problem that comes from the intersection of
several things.

The first thing to note is that the post-install scripts of the
kernel-core package use kernel-install [1].  For whatever reason, this
installs the kernel to /boot/MACHINE-ID/KERNEL-VERSION

MACHINE-ID comes from /etc/machine-id; a UUID that should have been
created by the systemd post-inst scripts with systemd-machine-id-setup
[2].

The chroot environment provided for root.d elements has no kernel
file-systems like /proc or /dev mounted.  This is where differences in
the base-system come into play -- on more recent systems that
implement getrandom() systemd does not need /dev/urandom to generate
the machine-id [3]; we get a value and /etc/machine-id is populated.

On older platforms (Trusty), systemd-machine-id-setup fails (unable to
access /dev/urandom) and we end up with a blank /etc/machine-id.  This
ends up making kernel-install (the script) fail during yum's
installation of kernel-core, which means the initrd is not installed
correctly.

We end up bailing out in fedora-minimal/install.d/99-ramdisk, where we
try to put the installed ramdisk in /boot for the later grub install
scripts to find.

The solution here is to mount the standard kernel file-systems within
the chroot before we try installing.

[1] http://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/kernel-install.html
[2] http://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/systemd-machine-id-setup.html
[3] https://github.com/systemd/systemd/blob/master/src/basic/random-util.c

Change-Id: Ibcce35da928f64e6a719b070bcc833346ee7ee92
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/83/239583/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $TARGET_ROOT/etc/yum.repos.d/*repo # Note this is not usually done for root.d elements (see # lib/common-functions:mount_proc_dev_sys) but it's important that # we have things like /dev/urandom around inside the chroot for # the rpm [pre|post]inst scripts within the packages. sudo mkdir -p $TARGET_ROOT/proc $TARGET_ROOT/dev $TARGET_ROOT/sys sudo mount -t proc none $TARGET_ROOT/proc sudo mount --bind /dev $TARGET_ROOT/dev sudo mount --bind /dev/pts $TARGET_ROOT/dev/pts sudo mount -t sysfs none $TARGET_ROOT/sys sudo umount $TARGET_ROOT/proc sudo umount $TARGET_ROOT/dev/pts sudo umount $TARGET_ROOT/dev sudo umount $TARGET_ROOT/sys

commit_message:
Added 'master_addresses' to Bay in API

A bay has an attribute 'node_addresses' that lists the IP addresses
of each minion node. As the support of HA mode was added, we need a
similar attribute, said 'master_addresses', that lists the IP
addresses of each master node.

Change-Id: I56313d273f4524095348f9cfd3bcb0f7b31054f6
Closes-Bug: #1483047
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/87/242887/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """IP addresses of cluster slave nodes""" master_addresses = wsme.wsattr([wtypes.text], readonly=True) """IP addresses of cluster master nodes"""

metadata: Switch to OpenStack namespace and bump to Kilo

This patch fixes the puppet forge namespace, and bump min dependency to
Kilo https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Puppet/releases.

commit_message:
DiskFileNoSpace check during object delete

On a full disk, a call to delete an object will fail when it tries to
write tombstones. Handling DiskFileNoSpace exception raised by
swift.common.utils.

Change-Id: I8f0cfcc4159ee154fcd3e7ca90c422aa5aadf0b3
Signed-off-by: Ganesh Maharaj Mahalingam <ganesh.mahalingam@intel.com>
Closes-Bug: 1491675
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/48/237648/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: disk_file.delete(req_timestamp) self.container_update( 'DELETE', account, container, obj, request, HeaderKeyDict({'x-timestamp': req_timestamp.internal}), device, policy) except DiskFileNoSpace: return HTTPInsufficientStorage(drive=device, request=request)
deleted_lines: disk_file.delete(req_timestamp) self.container_update( 'DELETE', account, container, obj, request, HeaderKeyDict({'x-timestamp': req_timestamp.internal}), device, policy)

subject: Add requestsexceptions to global requirements
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-11-03 18:13:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/cab316e4453a6bdbd689de5e3461ab7f60a9b263', 'message': 'Add requestsexceptions to global requirements

Source:
https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-infra/requestsexceptions

PyPI: https://pypi.python.org/pypi/requestsexceptions

Import exceptions from potentially bundled packages in requests.

The python requests library bundles the urllib3 library, however, some
software distributions modify requests to remove the bundled library.
This makes some operations, such as supressing the "insecure platform
warning" messages that urllib emits difficult. This is a simple library
to find the correct path to exceptions in the requests library regardless
of whether they are bundled.

Consuming projects
==================

This is used by shade.

This will be a proposed requirement of os-client-config.

Is the library actively maintained?
===================================

Yes, the library is actively maintained by the OpenStack Infra team.

The latest release was November 2015.

Is the library good code?
=========================

The actual library is very small, and although mostly undocumented, is
well structured and easy to follow:

http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-infra/requestsexceptions/tree/requestsexceptions/__init__.py

Is the library python 3 compatible?
===================================

Yes.

Is the library license compatible?
==================================

freezegun's LICENSE is Apache 2.0:

Is the library already packaged in the distros we target?
=========================================================

No, but there is no reason packaging it will be hard.

Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries?
===================================================================

Nope.

commit_message:
Add requestsexceptions to global requirements

Source:
https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-infra/requestsexceptions

PyPI: https://pypi.python.org/pypi/requestsexceptions

Import exceptions from potentially bundled packages in requests.

The python requests library bundles the urllib3 library, however, some
software distributions modify requests to remove the bundled library.
This makes some operations, such as supressing the "insecure platform
warning" messages that urllib emits difficult. This is a simple library
to find the correct path to exceptions in the requests library regardless
of whether they are bundled.

Consuming projects
==================

This is used by shade.

This will be a proposed requirement of os-client-config.

Is the library actively maintained?
===================================

Yes, the library is actively maintained by the OpenStack Infra team.

The latest release was November 2015.

Is the library good code?
=========================

The actual library is very small, and although mostly undocumented, is
well structured and easy to follow:

http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-infra/requestsexceptions/tree/requestsexceptions/__init__.py

Is the library python 3 compatible?
===================================

Yes.

Is the library license compatible?
==================================

requestsexceptions's LICENSE is Apache 2.0:

Is the library already packaged in the distros we target?
=========================================================

No, but there is no reason packaging it will be hard.

Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries?
===================================================================

Nope.

Change-Id: I52249b6d2fe04c49a9f4ed139d7625c890309ca8

commit_message:
Remove unused has_admin_extensions()

has_admin_extensions() had not been used since the commit
Id36a6ebddb618a78cee7025c9537cd1e2746190e.
So it is nice to remove it for cleanup.

Change-Id: Ie828bb82da4a6453f8934a8a85a23944bc4f4eed

deleted_lines: def has_admin_extensions(self): """ Returns True if the KSADM Admin Extensions are supported False otherwise """ if hasattr(self, '_has_admin_extensions'): return self._has_admin_extensions # Try something that requires admin try: self.list_roles() self._has_admin_extensions = True except Exception: self._has_admin_extensions = False return self._has_admin_extensions

commit_message:
split out k8s and api functional testing

This patch splits out api and functional testing case to different directory,
and modify post_test_hook.sh to passing a parameter to calling different tox
venv.


Depends-On: I10e09b2deea7a0643a9516701994cc47813e1aaa
Partially implements: blueprint split-gate-functional-dsvm-magnum
Change-Id: Ic33ea42f6108c7444c152706458cf1a686ed1756

commit_message:
Initial basic privsep functionality

Supports starting privileged process via fork or sudo, and a thread-safe
client and server communication mechanism.

Coming in later changes:
 - Extend json encoding to deal with non-unicode and more varied dict
   keys (see test_comm.py).
 - eventlet test case.
 - Linux capabilities.

Change-Id: If6456631c51d4f2a1c95805ab9d6962b04f172bc
Implements: blueprint privsep

subject: iboot: add wait loop for pstate to activate
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-11-02 20:44:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/e30d1a31fcdadaa37f13e9dafe5f9160808987c2', 'message': 'iboot: add wait loop for pstate to be effective

Add a short loop (10 seconds max) so that power state
changes can have some time to become active on iboot
devices with remote switches.

Closes bug: #1512478

Change-Id: Ifad4b6a22f0289b2bcec25528566326a2688e76b
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-11-03 15:44:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/1b72f84a0acfbe8e1b46b4439df5a00ba25f687c', 'message': 'iboot: add wait loop for pstate to be effective

Add a short retry loop so that power state changes can
have some time to become active on iboot devices with
remote switches.

commit_message:
iboot: add wait loop for pstate to activate

Add a short retry loop so that power state changes can
have some time to become active on iboot devices with
remote switches.

Closes bug: #1512478

Change-Id: Ifad4b6a22f0289b2bcec25528566326a2688e76b

commit_message:
Move ignore_dbs and ignore_users out of DEFAULT

ignore_dbs and ignore_users (for MySQL) were still in DEFAULT section
of config. Moved them to the 'mysql' section and 'percona'
section. Sample config file(s) have been updated as well.

Change-Id: I3a41bcb011a76343afa3bcc30013cb835e456950
Closes-Bug: #1465242
Closes-Bug: #1480448
Closes-Bug: #1480447
Closes-Bug: #1374004

"}]
commit_message:
Move supported messaging drivers in-tree

Up until now it has only been available in the OpenStack spec, but it is
a living document and I believe we can maintain it in oslo.messaging's
tree.

Change-Id: I7bb9e5f02004f857d8f75909fcc0d05f2882a77d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/08/240608/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ============================= Supported Messaging Drivers ============================= RabbitMQ may not be sufficient for the entire community as the community grows. Pluggability is still something we should maintain, but we should have a very high standard for drivers that are shipped and documented as being supported. This document defines a very clear policy as to the requirements for drivers to be carried in oslo.messaging and thus supported by the OpenStack community as a whole. We will deprecate any drivers that do not meet the requirements, and announce said deprecations in any appropriate channels to give users time to signal their needs. Deprecation will last for two release cycles before removing the code. We will also review and update documentation to annotate which drivers are supported and which are deprecated given these policies Policy ------ Testing ~~~~~~~ * Must have unit and/or functional test coverage of at least 60% as reported by coverage report. Unit tests must be run for all versions of python oslo.messaging currently gates on. * Must have integration testing including at least 3 popular oslo.messaging dependents, preferrably at the minimum a devstack-gate job with Nova, Cinder, and Neutron. * All testing above must be voting in the gate of oslo.messaging. Documentation ~~~~~~~~~~~~~ * Must have a reasonable amount of documentation including documentation in the official OpenStack deployment guide. Support ~~~~~~~ * Must have at least two individuals from the community commited to triaging and fixing bugs, and responding to test failures in a timely manner. Prospective Drivers ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ * Drivers that intend to meet the requirements above, but that do not yet meet them will be given one full release cycle, or 6 months, whichever is longer, to comply before being marked for deprecation. Their use, however, will not be supported by the community. This will prevent a chicken and egg problem for new drivers. .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

commit_message:
Ensure__repr__ return value is encoded

When __repr__ returns an unicode object, python will
try to encode it with the default encoding scheme
which is ascii in general. So __repr__ needs to make
sure its return value is properly encoded.

Change-Id: Ifdb8c073474a917207a48fc5af5a340e87f66fc4
Closes-Bug: #1514325

subject: Try to use zuul-cloner to prepare fixtures
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-11-05 07:05:05.000000000', 'files': ['.gitignore', '.fixtures.yml', 'Rakefile', 'Gemfile'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-horizon/commit/f1cf86c76e81242d6fcb0525129b5b53b62210e6', 'message': "Try to use zuul-cloner to prepare fixtures

In OpenStack Infra, we would like to run Puppet unit tests that
sometimes depends on other Puppet OpenStack modules.
Example: a patch in puppet-openstacklib that needs to be tested in puppet-nova.

This patch modifies the Rakefile to:
* clean spec_prep and spec_clean Rake tasks
* use openstack/puppet-openstack-integration/install_modules_unit.sh script
  to clone modules.
* do not use .fixtures.yaml file to clone modules and rely on
  zuul-cloner or git.
* Add openstack/ in gitignore so we never commit the
  puppet-openstack-integration repository (can happen when spec_clean
  did not run but you want to submit the patch anyway)
* Allow to run a custom Puppetfile if PUPPETFILE env is exported. It
  will allow people to test the module with the dependencies they like,
  feature we had with .fixtures.yaml.

Also add 'r10k' to Gemfile.

That way, we will be able to use zuul dependencies and run tests accross
modules like we do with functional testing.

Patch with original change-id I7b5af3ea6b21009a505a8b6c49086d339eaa43e5
for stable/kilo was merged without resolved comments.

Change-Id: I7f4169fa88bb4d5622a3e35b3ae2ff8a6380a514
"}]
commit_message:
Try to use zuul-cloner to prepare fixtures

In OpenStack Infra, we would like to run Puppet unit tests that
sometimes depends on other Puppet OpenStack modules.
Example: a patch in puppet-openstacklib that needs to be tested in puppet-nova.

This patch modifies the Rakefile to:
* clean spec_prep and spec_clean Rake tasks
* use openstack/puppet-openstack-integration/install_modules_unit.sh script
  to clone modules.
* do not use .fixtures.yaml file to clone modules and rely on
  zuul-cloner or git.
* Add openstack/ in gitignore so we never commit the
  puppet-openstack-integration repository (can happen when spec_clean
  did not run but you want to submit the patch anyway)
* Allow to run a custom Puppetfile if PUPPETFILE env is exported. It
  will allow people to test the module with the dependencies they like,
  feature we had with .fixtures.yaml.

Also add 'r10k' to Gemfile.

That way, we will be able to use zuul dependencies and run tests accross
modules like we do with functional testing.

Patch with original change-id I7b5af3ea6b21009a505a8b6c49086d339eaa43e5
for stable/kilo was merged without resolved comments.

Change-Id: I7f4169fa88bb4d5622a3e35b3ae2ff8a6380a514
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-horizon refs/changes/08/241908/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: group :system_tests do gem 'r10k', :require => 'false' end

commit_message:
Really get the "general" packages

We are specifying the argument to get_packages incorrectly, so we are
not actually adding the packages in "general" to the list of packages.

In most cases, this is hidden as other more specific plugins/services
request their packages.  However, as
I2dafd32f211fcbc9fff53030d736d97a5f1bb2df shows, not always.  I think
this was uncovered by 5f8133caac097235ed4fe73d878df0ee907eb51c

Change-Id: Ie1b8d09369281059d21da61b2725a457f708ae9e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/86/243086/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: PACKAGES=$(get_packages general,$ENABLED_SERVICES)

commit_message:
Use non-in-place sed to change hosts

Change-Id: I9f4e2c5988e05efbd3afbea99405981fcad68b0c
Closes-Bug: 1466715
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/22/194522/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Not to use 'sed -i', which does not run under docker container env, where # the /etc/hosts are mounted from host file cat /etc/hosts | sed -e "s/\(^127.0.0.1.*\)/\1 $LOCAL_HOSTNAME/" | sudo tee /etc/hosts > /dev/null fi if [ -z "`grep ^::1 /etc/hosts | grep $LOCAL_HOSTNAME`" ]; then cat /etc/hosts | sed -e "s/\(^::1.*\)/\1 $LOCAL_HOSTNAME/" | sudo tee /etc/hosts > /dev/null

commit_message:
Add spec for tooz driver policy

This does not contain the actual policy, as that should live in tooz's
code tree.

Change-Id: I796a8b493d65290899721515ed30b5680a540ead
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs refs/changes/73/240373/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ==================== Tooz Driver Policy ==================== OpenStack project teams have identified a number of opportunities for making use of distributed lock managers and the primitives that they provide. Tooz has traditionally included a number of drivers which meet the bare minimum requirements for some of these, but are deficient in many ways. Problem description =================== Given the weight that in-tree drivers will carry with users of OpenStack, there is a desire to ensure that users deploying will only be presented with choices of high quality that meet all of the requirements of the projects in OpenStack that consume tooz. Proposed change =============== Drivers that are not sufficient must be deprecated and eventually removed from tooz. They will still be consumable for downstreams of tooz that do not have the same requirements of all of the OpenStack projects. In order to identify which drivers are sufficient, a policy will be added to the documentation of tooz which provides the requirements for inclusion. This policy will be modeled on the oslo.messaging drivers policy. Alternatives ------------ Drivers could be classified in documentation, but kept in-tree. This would have minimum impact on tooz downstreams, but also add some risk to OpenStack deployers who might select tooz. The API of tooz could also be changed to force callers to express their needs and allow drivers to specify their assumptions aroune the capabilities of the tooz backend in use. This would be extremely complex and make tooz harder to consume. Impact on Existing APIs ----------------------- The API will be unchanged, but the configuration options available to downstreams of tooz will be more limited. Security impact --------------- This will lower the surface area of tooz slightly. Performance Impact ------------------ Some backends are deficient entirely because they are non-performant or non-scalable. So this reduces the risk of a user of OpenStack encountering performance problems. Configuration Impact -------------------- Some backends will not be available anymore, or will cause deprecation warnings. The drivers will not be removed for several cycles after deprecation, so this is a long-term impact. Developer Impact ---------------- Testing requirements on backends will be elevated, so developers will need to spend more effort on backends, especially on new drivers. Testing Impact -------------- Drivers will need to have a higher level of test coverage. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: clint-fewbar (SpamapS) Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: mitaka-1 Work Items ---------- * Write policy in tooz documentation Documentation Impact ==================== N/A Dependencies ============ N/A References ========== https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/mitaka-cross-project-dlm .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

commit_message:
Unify common output keys across Heat templates

After this commit, all Heat templates have five common outputs:
* api_address: API endpoint of specific COE.
* kube_masters/swarm_master/mesos_master: Public IP address(es) of
  master node(s).
* kube_masters_private/swarm_master_private/mesos_master_private:
  Private IP address(es) of master node(s).
* kube_minions/swarm_nodes/mesos_slaves: List of public IP addresses
  of worker nodes.
* kube_minions_private/swarm_nodes_private/mesos_slaves_private:
  List of private IP addresses of worker nodes.

Change-Id: Ie44136dafa326db598a5f17978d89adce8e69801
Closes-Bug: #1514252

'}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2015-11-09 08:36:09.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/virt/libvirt/storage/test_rbd.py', 'nova/virt/libvirt/storage/rbd_utils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/474e7bb3f356e7e7592a249dcf2053659fe8cf38', 'message': "Fix attibute error when cloning raw images in Ceph

"}]
commit_message:
Fix attibute error when cloning raw images in Ceph

A regression introduced in If03b166d3ecc3e7fa6b7f1a0c69f8ab1cc7b1972
causes a glance image with the type 'raw' in ceph to fail to CoW
clone which prevents launching at all in this case.

The original patch did not update imagebackend.py [1] to use the new
nova.objects.ImageMeta object so the clone() function passes a normal
dict to the is_cloneable() function.

Additionally add another test to ensure that not passing disk_format
will fail, but not result in an exception. It will simply mean that
the function returns that it cannot take advantage of the CoW cloning
ceph provides.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f2e2a5891d5f5ff9346e6dc8e4dd0e994485245c/nova/virt/libvirt/imagebackend.py#L824

Change-Id: I7ae107bfccab7ff66c09d96856722dd6e60fdd96
Closes-Bug: #1508230
(cherry picked from commit 835ff1bf73d36a311168283f8a4ef5bec03d5a7e)

added_lines: if image_meta.get('disk_format') != 'raw': url, image_meta.get('disk_format'))

commit_message:
Use oslo.middleware SSLMiddleware

This change replaces Heat homemade SSLMiddleware by oslo.middleware
one. SSLMiddleware now should be defined in oslo_middleware section
instead of DEFAULT one (which is deprecated).

commit_message:
Fix Kuryr not to create the duplicated port on creatign an endpoint

This patch fixes Kuryr to examine if a port with the same name exist
before creating it and create a new one only when it doesn't exist yet.

With --cluster-store for the Docker daemon, the API call against a
remote driver on a host is propergated to other remote drivers. In this
situation if /NetworkDriver.CreateEndpoint is called, Kuryr tries to
create the duplicated port on different hosts and got the
MacAddressInUseClient exception from the Neutron client like one below.

MacAddressInUseClient: Unable to complete operation for network
0802076e-6a5a-4add-aa51-10a90d909e9d. The mac address fa:16:3e:eb:6e:13
is in use.

Change-Id: I1f805cf7e7f1312997be1b190caffa2f8634b31b
Signed-off-by: Taku Fukushima <f.tac.mac@gmail.com>
Closes-Bug: #1509197

commit_message:
Move install of simport to virtualenv setup

Move the simport install to the virtaulenv setup
section so that individual components do have
to have the extra parameters in their install
commands.

Change-Id: I19fa075e12a7ff4336ba027e1d575bb6f44845d7

commit_message:
Enable network services at Kub master

It's common practice
(https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/tree/master/cluster) to run
network services (kube-proxy and flannel) at master. E.g. you can use
NodePort
(http://kubernetes.io/v1.0/docs/user-guide/services.html#type-nodeport)
for opening services to outside cluster. Flannel will be used later for
Kub services containerization (e.g.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/240818)

Change-Id: I25b5f3c5931dab5d410702ab3737eea2f207ec35

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-21 06:59:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/eb856373088688f1ca35298d39f122b2f3bf447e', 'message': "ovs: ovs agent updates the wrong port when using Xen + Neutron

Problem:
When VM is under HVM mode, ovs will create two ports and two interfaces for
a single virtual ethernet interface inside the VM: One is named as tapx.0
which is qemu-emulated NIC, used when no PV drivers installed; The other
one is named as vifx.0 which is the xen network frontend NIC, used when
VM has PV drivers installed. Depending on the PV driver's existing,
either of the two ports/interfaces will be used. But current implement
can NOT process multiple ports/interfaces. If it configures(e.g. set tag)
one interface but the other one is in fact used by ovs; it will have
network problem.

Solution:
When there are two ports/interfaces, one is active and the other is
inactive. Follow the existing working for the active one; but also
add fields to holde the inactive one. And try to apply same conf to
both ports.

Change-Id: Ic00d2cd83ef4104388df42c97118b02be30b22be

commit_message:
ovs: ovs agent updates the wrong port when using Xen + Neutron

Note:
 This patch set is still WIP; Need to cover UT code and refine code.
 Any comments for the design or else are welcome and appreciated.

Problem description:
When VM is under HVM mode, ovs will create two ports and two interfaces for
a single virtual ethernet interface inside the VM: One is named as tapx.0
which is qemu-emulated NIC, used when no PV drivers installed; The other
one is named as vifx.0 which is the xen network frontend NIC, used when
VM has PV drivers installed. Depending on the PV driver's existing,
either of the two ports/interfaces will be used. But current implement
can NOT process multiple ports/interfaces. If it configures(e.g. set tag)
one interface but the other one is in fact used by ovs; it will have
network problem.

Solution:
When there are two ports/interfaces, one is active and the other is
inactive. Follow the existing working for the active one; but also
add fields to holde the inactive one. And try to apply same conf to
both ports.

Change-Id: Ic00d2cd83ef4104388df42c97118b02be30b22be
Closes-Bug: #1268955
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/00/237900/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def __init__(self, port_name, ofport, vif_id, vif_mac, switch, inactive_pname=None, inactive_ofport=None): # there may be two port choices for one single vif # inside the VM; but one of them should be active # and the other one should be inactive; and they # share the same other fields except the port name # and ofport. self.inactive_pname = inactive_pname self.inactive_ofport = inactive_ofport self.switch.br_name + "inactive_pname=" + self.inactive_pname + "inactive_ofport=" + str(self.inactive_ofport)) def get_all_ports(self): ports = [{'pname': self.port_name, 'ofport': self.ofport}] if self.inactive_pname: port = {'pname': self.inactive_pname, 'ofport': self.inactive_ofport} ports.append(port) return ports def get_all_pnames(self): return [p['pname'] for p in self.get_all_ports()] def get_all_ofports(self): return [p['ofport'] for p in self.get_all_ports()] def bind_to_vlan(self, vlan_mapping): for port_name in self.get_all_pnames(): port_other_config = self.switch.db_get_val("Port", port_name, "other_config") port_other_config.update(vlan_mapping) self.switch.set_db_attribute("Port", port_name, "other_config", port_other_config) def delete_flows(self): for ofport in self.get_all_ofports(): self.switch.delete_flows(in_port=ofport) def set_tag(self, vlan): for port_name in self.get_all_pnames(): self.switch.set_db_attribute( "Port", port_name, "tag", vlan) def delete_arp_spoofing_protection(self): for ofport in self.get_all_ofports(): self.switch.delete_arp_spoofing_protection(port=ofport) def install_icmpv6_na_spoofing_protection(self, ipv6_addresses): for ofport in self.get_all_ofports(): self.switch.install_icmpv6_na_spoofing_protection( port=ofport, ip_addresses=ipv6_addresses) def install_arp_spoofing_protection(self, ipv4_addresses): for ofport in self.get_all_ofports(): self.switch.install_arp_spoofing_protection( port=ofport, ip_addresses=ipv4_addresses) def _get_vif_ports(self): # return ports dict with port_id as the key edge_ports = {} inact_ports = {} port_id = None if "attached-mac" in external_ids: port_id = self.portid_from_external_ids(external_ids) if port_id: if not self._check_ofport(port_id, port_info): # skip if ofport is not ready continue if (external_ids.get('iface-status') == 'inactive'): # save inactive ports as the inact_ports inact_ports[port_id] = {'pname': name, 'ofport': ofport} else: edge_ports[port_id] = VifPort( name, ofport, port_id, external_ids["attached-mac"], self) # attach the inactive ports to their active port object. for port_id in inact_ports: port_name = inact_ports[port_id]['pname'] ofport = inact_ports[port_id]['ofport'] # just in case if port_id in edge_ports: LOG.info(_LI("no active port for %(id)s, port_name=%(name)s"), {'id': port_id, 'name': port_name}) continue edge_ports[port_id].inactive_pname = port_name edge_ports[port_id].inactive_ofport = ofport # commit_message:
Continuous systems management in Security Guide

In References section
The "OpenStack Security Primer" has a link where the music
piracy blog doesn't exist. The owner took it down. So this fix
is to remove the reference to it.

Change-Id: I206c249af1bc27732dd07489ccb8d687fe3343b7
Closes-bug: #1510806

""" db_cert = cls.dbapi.get_x509keypair_by_bay_uuid(context, bay_uuid) return X509KeyPair._from_db_object(cls(context), db_cert)

added_lines: configurations for Glance - which include the version in the URL - but rather notify the deployer that the new expected value has changed and the configuration file should be updated. During the Mitaka cycle, we can strip the verion from the URL to discover what versions of the API are deployed and favor 2 over 1 when possible. Therefore, we'll support both, versioned and unversioned, URLs during Mitaka and then we'll switch to the later only.This will require deployers to have Glance Mitaka deployed and it won't be backwards compatible with regards to the Glance's API.
deleted_lines: It is assumed that Nova's lack of support for Glance v2 is causing confusion that is holding people back from deploying Glance v2. This in turn is causing some problems for the DefCore effort. configurations for Glance - which include the version in the URL - but rather notify the deployer that the new expected value has changed and the configuration file should be updated. During the Mitaka cycle, we can strip the verion from the URL to discover what versions of the API are deployed and favor 2 over 1 when possible.

Moving Nested Quota Driver to Mitaka

Nested quota driver will enable OpenStack to enforce quota in nested
projects.

Previously-approved: Liberty

commit_message:
New local certificate generator uses local time

The new local certificate generator code uses local time
for validity periods causing failures on hosts that do not
use UTC time.
This patch changes this to always use UTC time for certificate
generation.

Change-Id: Ice15ab53f322ac148c85e1f6e781f63f661d6179
Closes-Bug: #1514601

deleted_lines: valid_from_datetime = datetime.datetime.today() valid_to_datetime = datetime.datetime.now() + datetime.timedelta( seconds=validity)

commit_message:
dib-lint: ignore blank lines in element ordering

Some of the elements-deps in the project-config repo have a blank line
at the end, which throws out the ordering.  Strip blank lines, like
comment lines, before processing.

As an additional help, show a side-by-side diff of what is provided
versus what is expected when showing an error about sorting.

Change-Id: I007851ee01d6853ad992ce4437331e8bd79bbfce

added_lines: grep -v -e '^#' -e '^$' $i > ${UNSORTED} diff -y ${UNSORTED} ${SORTED}

commit_message:
Pull the endpoint from the Session

If the user passes a Session in, we can pull the endpoint to use for
discovery from the Session itself, rather than erroring.

Closes-Bug: #1513839
Co-Authored-By: Dolph Mathews <dolph.mathews@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I82a41c67f80d2494f04739d82b112b7ff1dc4682
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/95/242495/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cs = client.Client(session=s)

commit_message:
Initial checkin

This adds most of the files from app-catalog-ui into this common
location so it can be shared soon with app-catalog-ui and
apps.openstack.org. Its currently only usable by apps.openstack.org
and will need further work to be shared. But its a start.

Change-Id: I63bff3be6180ff12ab0055c15ff04fd4a7631684

subject: EC GET path: support use of alternate fragments on object servers
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-14 13:38:12.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/3a7525c9c1f8f34cc9261eb4f5a5805ac7be1c43', 'message': 'EC GET path: support use of alternate fragments on object servers

Changes include:
- storage nodes reporting when they have >1 fragment archive
available
- GET path recognizing alternates, when to use them and building
up the getters accordingly leveraging existing greenpool
- associated test changes for existing code
- new unit tests and new probe tests

Change-Id: Id21853498af9f424fe5f5cf7f37017e89a4d67b9
Closes-Bug: 1484598
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-08-14 16:28:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/dee427aff63422925d5ec40cc560b3806dc601ee', 'message': 'EC GET path: support use of alternate fragments on object servers

Changes include:
- storage nodes reporting when they have >1 fragment archive
available
- GET path recognizing alternates, when to use them and building
up the getters accordingly leveraging existing greenpool
- HEAD reports available alt frags
- associated test changes for existing code
- new unit tests and new probe tests

Note:  non-EC policies ignore alt-frag headers

Change-Id: Id21853498af9f424fe5f5cf7f37017e89a4d67b9
Closes-Bug: 1484598
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-08-19 11:55:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/7c01fff2ca4a00413571f6f32455e8d6ee360c2a', 'message': 'EC GET path: support use of alternate fragments on object servers

Changes include:
- storage nodes reporting when they have >1 fragment archive
available
- GET path recognizing alternates, when to use them and building
up the getters accordingly leveraging existing greenpool
- HEAD reports available alt frags
- associated test changes for existing code

commit_message:
EC GET path: support use of alternate fragments on object servers

Changes include:
- storage nodes reporting when they have >1 fragment archive
available
- GET path recognizing alternates, when to use them and building
up the getters accordingly leveraging existing greenpool
- HEAD reports available alt frags
- associated test changes for existing code
- new unit tests and new probe tests

Note:  non-EC policies ignore alt-frag headers

Co-Authored-By: Alistair Coles <alistair.coles@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Minwoo Bae <minwoob@us.ibm.com>
Change-Id: Id21853498af9f424fe5f5cf7f37017e89a4d67b9
Closes-Bug: 1484598

commit_message:
Parse Sample volume as float

Explicitly parses sample volume as float to
prevent incorrect sample from being published.
In case of an sample with wrong volume type or
no volume. the sample is dropped and a warning
is logged.

Change-Id: Ia81d309876ba4a358d8d8187e11a08867fb0b267
Closes-Bug: #1508220

commit_message:
Update multi-initiator extra-spec in Nimble doc

This patch updates the Nimble volume documentation to include
the multi-initiator extra spec as updated by
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/234422/.

Change-Id: I3df1e1d23a4e37726f71d7872d7d7be019c6d9d8
Closes-Bug: #1514005

commit_message:
remove py26 and py33 test

OpenStack has dropped the support for old python version 2.6, we can follow
it to reduce our maintain burden and save CI resources.
And we already have py34 test, which is enabled on Gerrit by default,
py33 test is not necessary now.

Change-Id: Ie2904d040ab86817c852b2f39b542814441e4dc3
Closes-Bug: #1500239

commit_message:
Move policy update logic to cluster

This patch makes update_policy a method of the cluster class. The intent
is to make it reusable outside an action context. Update policy is
useful when, for example, temporarily disable a policy on a cluster.

Change-Id: I6417539792dfb1485ac93492cb4bf858b676bc7f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/52/241952/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_do_update_policy(self, mock_load): cluster.update_policy.return_value = True, 'Success' 'foo': 'bar', self.assertEqual('Success.', res_msg) cluster.update_policy.assert_called_once_with( action.context, 'FAKE_POLICY', foo='bar') def test_do_update_policy_failed_update(self, mock_load): cluster = mock.Mock() cluster.id = 'FAKE_CLUSTER' cluster.update_policy.return_value = False, 'Someting is wrong.' mock_load.return_value = cluster action = ca.ClusterAction(cluster.id, 'CLUSTER_ACTION', self.ctx) action.inputs = { 'policy_id': 'FAKE_POLICY', 'foo': 'bar', } # do it res_code, res_msg = action.do_update_policy() self.assertEqual(action.RES_ERROR, res_code) self.assertEqual('Something is wrong.', res_msg) cluster.update_policy.assert_called_once_with( action.context, 'FAKE_POLICY', foo='bar') cluster.id = 'FAKE_CLUSTER'
deleted_lines: @mock.patch.object(db_api, 'cluster_policy_update') def test_do_update_policy(self, mock_update, mock_load): existing = mock.Mock() existing.id = 'FAKE_POLICY' cluster.policies = [existing] 'cooldown': 10, 'level': 20, 'priority': 30, 'enabled': False, self.assertEqual('Policy updated.', res_msg) mock_update.assert_called_once_with( action.context, 'FAKE_CLUSTER', 'FAKE_POLICY', {'cooldown': 10, 'level': 20, 'priority': 30, 'enabled': False}) cluster.id = 'CID' def test_do_update_policy_not_attached(self, mock_load): cluster = mock.Mock() cluster.policies = [] mock_load.return_value = cluster action = ca.ClusterAction(cluster.id, 'CLUSTER_ACTION', self.ctx) action.inputs = { 'policy_id': 'FAKE_POLICY', 'level': 20, } # do it res_code, res_msg = action.do_update_policy() self.assertEqual(action.RES_ERROR, res_code) self.assertEqual('Policy not attached.', res_msg) def test_do_update_policy_no_update_needed(self, mock_load): cluster = mock.Mock() existing = mock.Mock() existing.id = 'FAKE_POLICY' cluster.policies = [existing] mock_load.return_value = cluster action = ca.ClusterAction(cluster.id, 'CLUSTER_ACTION', self.ctx) action.inputs = { 'policy_id': 'FAKE_POLICY', } # do it res_code, res_msg = action.do_update_policy() self.assertEqual(action.RES_OK, res_code) self.assertEqual('No update is needed.', res_msg)

commit_message:
Update TODO/FEATURE item list

This patch updates TODO.rst and FEATURE.rst based on the
discussion in Tokyo meetup. The backlogs of Liberty cycle are
picked up and some TODO items which are in long-term plan are
moved from TODO.rst to FEATURES.rst.

Change-Id: I799deb7adb3abbe066ac92f0f2cdbd0acc4265d3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/64/240764/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: API --- - Make object creation/updating requests return code 202, since most of them are done asynchronously in Senlin. - Make object creation requests return both action_id and a location header set to the URI of the resource to be created. This is a requirement from API WG. - API resource names should not include underscores. A guideline from API WG. [Lv Dongbin] Health Management ----------------- - Provide an option for user to define the threshold of cluster health status classification. - Support do_check/do_recover in profiles. - Support cluster/node health status refresh and expose API interface: By default, 'cached' health status of Senlin objects will be provided to user. Object health status will only be refreshed when user requests initiatively. - Provide support for watching all objects we created on behalf of users, like loadbalancer which is created when attaching lb policy. - Leverage other monitoring services for object health status monitoring. Trigger ------- - Ceilometer (Aodh) alarm based triggers [Qiming] Receiver -------- - Provide another abstraction layer to generalize the design of receiver in Senlin. We only support receiver type of webhook in current stage. But we should expose receiver rather than webhook API interfaces to enduser. - Add support to have Senlin API run under Apache. [Haiwei] - Scavenger of objects. We may need a seperate deamon to periodically clean DB. - Lock breaker in multi-engine environment. - Batching policy: create batchs for node creation/deletion/update Trigger ------- - Monasca alarm based triggers - Zaqar message queue based triggers [Ethan Lynn]ENGINE ------ - User Defined Actions - Use Barbican to store Senlin credential, e.g. user name/id, password, trust_id - Document Senlin health management mechanism - Give a sample end-to-end story to demonstrate how to use Senlin for autoscaling scenario
deleted_lines: - Investigate the impact of node-create and node-delete on certain policies. - Make object creation requests return code 202, since most creation are done asynchronously in Senlin. - Make object creation requests return a location header set to the URI of the resource to be created. This is a requirement from API WG. - API resource names should not include underscores. A guideline from API WG. - Add support to have Senlin API run under Apache. - Health policy

subject: Agent Group and Tooz Driver
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-04-16 15:45:38.000000000', 'files': ['specs/liberty/agent-group.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs/commit/224feaad0472bb1d951e46eb1d50a83b885bbd91', 'message': 'Agent Group and Tooz Driver

Proper operations in Neutron depends on agent monitoring information
and health status. Currently there is a heartbeat/DB based mechanism.
It is not instant, extremely inefficient and not scalable.

A much more lightweight, scalable and reliable agent status monitoring
and querying mechanism is desired for neutron. We would like to introduce
AgentGroup to neutron, which provides internal API for neutron agent
grouping, membership registration, health status check, group member

Blueprint: agent-group-and-tooz-driver

commit_message:
Agent Group and Tooz Driver

Proper operations in Neutron depends on agent monitoring information
and health status. Currently there is a heartbeat/DB based mechanism.
It is not instant, extremely inefficient and not scalable.

A much more lightweight, scalable and reliable agent status monitoring
and querying mechanism is desired for neutron. We would like to introduce
AgentGroup to neutron, which provides internal API for neutron agent
grouping, membership registration, health status check, group member
querying, etc. Modules such as failure detective, scheduler and HA will
use AgentGroup and its API.

There are many different backend which can be used to implement those
functionalities in AgentGroup. Instead of having neutron to maintain,
test, upgrade those code, we intend to introduce a tooz driver, and use
tooz library to manage/maintain 3rd party backend such as zookeeper, redis,
etc. Also, considering backward compatibility with original DB-based
mechanism, since it uses tables and data model that is intrinsically tied
to the internal of neutron, tooz cannot take it over. So a DB-based driver
is needed for AgentGroup, just the same as how nova ServiceGroup refactoring
spec solves the compatibility issue.

Change-Id: I1cdb832abc9c42a218cfb975c946eac87108d8da
Blueprint: agent-group-and-tooz-driver
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/38/174438/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================== Agent Group and Tooz Driver ============================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/agent-group-and-tooz-driver Neutron needs to maintain up-to-date information of its variant agents, especially the health status of each agent, to apply proper operations on them and provide stable services to end users. For example, schedulers always make sure the agent is alive before assigning tasks. HA periodically checks agent failure to decide whether trigger a recovery operation. Currently, this is done by agent heartbeat message, and DB persistence of heartbeat information. Agent periodically sends heartbeat message to neutron-server(by default every 30 seconds). Heartbeat timestamp and agent configuration information is parsed on server side and written into DB. When scheduler or HA needs to get agent status, those records should be retrieved from DB and compared with agent_down_time. Neutron server cost is not trivial and the cost increases when scale gets bigger. This mechanism is extremely inefficient and not scalable. A much more lightweight, scalable and reliable agent status monitoring and querying mechanism is desired for neutron. We would like to introduce AgentGroup to neutron, which provides internal API for neutron agent grouping, membership registration, health status check, group member querying, etc. Modules such as failure detective, scheduler and HA will use AgentGroup and its API. There are many different backend which can be used to implement those functionalities in AgentGroup. Instead of having neutron to maintain, test, upgrade those code(proposed in previous spec[1]), we intend to introduce a tooz driver, and use tooz library(new oslo lib, see[2]) to manage/maintain 3rd party backend such as zookeeper, memcached, redis, etc. Also, we should guarantee backward compatibility for original DB-based mechanism. Since it uses tables and data model that is intrinsically tied to the internal of neutron, tooz cannot take it over. So a DB-based driver is needed for AgentGroup, just the same as how nova ServiceGroup refactoring spec solves the compatibility issue.[3] For more information about nova ServiceGroup and its old implementation, see[4][5]. Problem Description =================== Efficiency and scalability issue of current agent heartbeat reporting and health status checking mechanism: 1. Agents send heartbeat messages periodically, while neutron server needs to parse information and write into DB. Under large scale the cost is not trivial. To discover agent failure as soon as possible, we tend to configure "report_interval" smaller. But considering server workload, user must make a choice between instantaneity and stability. The default value is 30s in neutron configuration file. 2. To determine an agent failure, heartbeat record should be retrieved from DB. Timestamp of last heartbeat is checked to see whether it exceeds down time window. Again, when scheduler needs to check all agents status while making a scheduling decision, this cost is not trivial. 3. To make sure an agent is truly down, instead of a misinterpretation caused by message delay/loss, user should configure "agent_down_time" which must be longer than "report_interval". The default down time value is 75 seconds. DB based status check mechanism can not discover agent failure instantly. It might be 75s later when we know it's down. That is obviously a little longer. 4. HA is not timely. HA waits even longer time before triggering failover. For example, DHCP Agent HA uses a bigger time window, agent_dead_limit(150s) to determine an agent is down before applying recovery operations. 5. No abstraction layer to hide backend details and provide internal API for neutron to use. Currently scheduler/HA has to manipulate specific backend(DB) directly. Proposed Change =============== * Add a thin abstraction layer: AgentGroup and its internal API 1. backend management details will be handled by tooz for all backend except db, which tooz could not take over as explained in previous section; 2. provide API for membership registration, monitoring, health status querying; 3. aggregate agents into groups by type, maintain membership for each group; 4. support fetching all alive agents at one API call, which is useful for scheduler and HA; * AgentGroup driver base class *could* be something like: (similar as nova ServiceGroup [3]) class AgentGroupDriverBase(object): def join(self, member_id, group_id, service=None): raise NotImplementedError() def is_up(self, member): raise NotImplementedError() def leave(self, member_id, group_id): raise NotImplementedError() def get_all(self, group_id): raise NotImplementedError() def get_one(self, group_id): raise NotImplementedError() * Add tooz driver *could* be something like: (similar as nova ServiceGroup [3]) class ToozServiceGroupDriver(ServiceGroupDriver): def __init__(self, backend_url): self._impl = tooz.get_coordinator(backend_url) self._impl.start() def join(self, member_id, group_id, service=None): # Call into impl to join (and handle/translate the # appropriate errors)... def is_up(self, member): # Call into impl to check if the member is up... (and # handle/translate the appropriate errors)... def leave(self, member_id, group_id): # Call into impl to leave (and handle/translate the appropriate # errors)... def get_all(self, group_id): # Call into impl to get all the members of the given group (and # handle/translate appropriate errors)... def get_one(self, group_id): # Call into impl to get one the members of the given group (and # handle/translate appropriate errors)... * Refactoring old DB-based implementation according to new API 1. New DB backend is in a driver modality; 2. provide backward-compatibility; Nova ServiceGroup also keeps this driver after using tooz; [3] 3. existing implementation uses tables and data model that is intrinsically tied to the internal of neutron, tooz cannot take it over. So a DB-based driver is needed for AgentGroup. See tables below: mysql> describe agents; +---------------------+---------------+------+-----+---------+-------+ | Field | Type | Null | Key | Default | Extra | +---------------------+---------------+------+-----+---------+-------+ | id | varchar(36) | NO | PRI | NULL | | | agent_type | varchar(255) | NO | MUL | NULL | | | binary | varchar(255) | NO | | NULL | | | topic | varchar(255) | NO | | NULL | | | host | varchar(255) | NO | | NULL | | | admin_state_up | tinyint(1) | NO | | 1 | | | created_at | datetime | NO | | NULL | | | started_at | datetime | NO | | NULL | | | heartbeat_timestamp | datetime | NO | | NULL | | | description | varchar(255) | YES | | NULL | | | configurations | varchar(4095) | NO | | NULL | | | load | int(11) | NO | | 0 | | +---------------------+---------------+------+-----+---------+-------+ 12 rows in set (0.00 sec) * (optional) refactoring HA mechanism, don't wait a long time before failover * (optional) replace periodical scanning into event trigger mode Data Model Impact ----------------- None. REST API Impact --------------- None. Security Impact --------------- None. Notifications Impact -------------------- None. Currently we will not change any existing notification mechanism. In the future, when use event trigger to replace periodical scanning, some notification changes may occur. Other End User Impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ * For DB-based driver, the performance would be similar with existing agent status monitoring/querying code; * For tooz driver, performance influence depends on which specific backend you configured for tooz. Take zookeeper as an example, a better performance should be gained: 1. Neutron Server doesn't need to use agent heartbeat message and its timestamp to determine agent liveness. So Agent doesn't need to set report_interval very small to get a better failure detection sensibility. User can set report_interval to a proper value, to let server get agent configuration/workload information. In that way, server burden for processing heartbeat and writing DB will decline. 2. When scheduler/HA tries to check agent liveness, it reduces server cost on DB querying and timestamp comparison, especially when check all agents. 3. No need to set a longer down_time(75s). Instant failure detection. 4. HA and failover will be timely. IPv6 Impact ----------- None. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- 1. New config options will be introduced, for user to specify which backend driver to use. Default driver will be DB-based AgentGroup driver, for backward compatibility. For other backends, choose tooz driver. 2. If use DB-based driver, there would be no difference for deployment. 3. If use tooz driver, config options that needed by tooz should be added, to indicate which specific backend tooz will use. Also, corresponding backend should be prepared correctly. Developer Impact ---------------- After internal API is introduced, new agent implementation, or new features that queries agent status, will use this new API. Community Impact ---------------- This allows admin/user to get an open framework for agent membership management, health status querying, and allow to introduce multiple different backends to achieve that. Will fully discuss with community to do it in a way that does not increase community maintenance or burden. Alternatives ------------ 1. Keep existing implementation. 2. Instead of using tooz to take care of variant backend, there's a previous spec in which AgentGroup takes care of zk/memcached backend.[1] Since we have tooz in oslo now, it'll be better not to choose this solution. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Robin Wang (launchpad-id: robinwang) Work Items ---------- * Add AgentGroup and internal API * Add tooz driver * Refactoring old DB-based implementation according to new API * (optional) refactoring HA mechanism, don't wait a long time before failover * (optional) replace periodical scanning into event trigger mode Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= Tempest Tests ------------- None. Functional Tests ---------------- Functional tests will be considered for the new implementation. API Tests --------- Tests for new added internal API will be considered. Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ * New added config options * Deployment related information for tooz and new backend. Developer Documentation ----------------------- Document new added internal API and usage. References ========== [1] Previous AgentGroup Spec https://review.openstack.org/#/c/168921/5/specs/liberty/agent-group.rst [2] Tooz, a new oslo library for distributed coordination http://docs.openstack.org/developer/tooz/ [3] Nova ServiceGroup refactoring with tooz https://review.openstack.org/#/c/138607/11/specs/liberty/approved/service-group-using-tooz.rst [4] Nova ServiceGroup old implementation, BP https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/zk-service-heartbeat [5] Nova ServiceGroup old implementation, wiki page https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/NovaZooKeeperHeartbeat

subject: Refactoring of L3 Scheduler
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-19 09:43:19.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs/commit/c1ac2c1a9971ba9b4677d2223b79f22db567ac66', 'message': 'Refactoring of L3 Scheduler

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/dhcpservice-loadbalancing

In the above mentioned blueprint, WeightScheduler has been introduced which
is used to effectively distribute the DHCP namespaces by checking the load on
each dhcp agent. DHCP agent load is calculated based on report status messages
received from them. The “dhcp service loadbalancing” blueprint had also
implemented BaseScheduler and BaseResourceFilter class hierarchy which should
be common for both dhcp_agent_scheduler and l3_agent_scheduler, however as of
now only dhcp_agent_scheduler is derived from BaseScheduler and updates the
load column of agents table.

This blueprint proposes refactoring of existing L3 Scheduler code to align
with the new design as implemented for dhcp Scheduler.

Change-Id: I89129c507d6b55b3c1546b522800661c22222a03
Co-Authored-By: Shivakumar M <shiva.kum.m@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Praveen Kumar SM <praveen-sm.kumar@hp.com>

This blueprint proposes refactoring of existing L3 Scheduler code to align

commit_message:
Refactoring of L3 Scheduler

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/dhcpservice-loadbalancing

In the above mentioned blueprint, WeightScheduler has been introduced which
is used to effectively distribute the DHCP namespaces by checking the load on
each dhcp agent. DHCP agent load is calculated based on report status messages
received from them. The “dhcp service loadbalancing” blueprint had also
implemented BaseScheduler and BaseResourceFilter class hierarchy which should
be common for both dhcp_agent_scheduler and l3_agent_scheduler, however as of
now only dhcp_agent_scheduler is derived from BaseScheduler and updates the
load column of agents table.

This blueprint proposes refactoring of existing L3 Scheduler code to align
with the new design as implemented for dhcp Scheduler.

Co-Authored-By: Shivakumar M <shiva.kum.m@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Praveen Kumar SM <praveen-sm.kumar@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Aman Kumar <aman.kumar3@hpe.com>

Related-bug: #1509046

Change-Id: I89129c507d6b55b3c1546b522800661c22222a03
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/15/184215/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================== Refactoring of L3 Scheduler =========================== Launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/refactoring-of-l3-scheduler Problem Description =================== Currently L3 scheduler code is aligned with dhcp scheduler. Below blueprint was implemented to distribute the DHCP namespace services when there are multiple Network Nodes available. https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/dhcpservice-loadbalancing In the above mentioned blueprint, WeightScheduler has been introduced which is used to effectively distribute the DHCP namespaces by checking the load on each dhcp agent. DHCP agent load is calculated based on report status messages received from them. The “dhcp service loadbalancing” blueprint had also implemented BaseScheduler and BaseResourceFilter class hierarchy which should be common for both dhcp_agent_scheduler and l3_agent_scheduler, however as of now only dhcp_agent_scheduler is derived from BaseScheduler and updates the load column of agents table. The current l3 agent scheduler logic is missing RouterFilter class which is supposed to bind the agents to the routers similar to DHCPFilter class. L3_agent_scheduler has LeastRouterScheduler to choose the l3 agents having minimum number of routers. But currently it is not derived from the BaseSheduler and BaseResourceFilter classes, hence there is duplication of code in LeastRouterScheduler and ChanceScheduler of l3_agent_scheduler which needs to be refactored. Also l3_agent_scheduler needs to update the load column based on l3 agent report status so that it can be consumed by LeastRouterScheduler. The class name LeastRouterScheduler will be renamed as WeightScheduler from l3_agent_scheduler perspective. Proposed Change =============== This blueprint proposes refactoring of existing L3 Scheduler code to align with the new design as implemented for dhcp Scheduler. The idea here is to abstract scheduling and binding logic, so that it will be common across L3 and DHCP schedulers. In this proposal, a new config variable ‘l3_load_type’ will be added in neutron.conf which will decide the load type of l3 agents and update the load column of agents table and schedule new router resource to the least loaded l3 agent based on load column value. It will also help to eliminate code duplication across l3 and dhcp schedulers. As the BaseScheduler is common for ChanceScheduler and WeightedScheduler, ChanceScheduler logic will also be refactored to align with the new class hierarchy. New class named RouterFilter will be introduced which will contain agents to routers binding logic. Data Model Impact ----------------- None REST API Impact --------------- None Security Impact --------------- None Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None IPv6 Impact ----------- None Other Deployer Impact --------------------- The load based l3 agent scheduling can be enabled by setting the below parameters router_scheduler_driver = neutron.scheduler.l3_agent_scheduler.WeightScheduler l3_load_type = routers which are configurable from “neutron.conf”. Developer Impact ---------------- None Community Impact ---------------- None Alternatives ------------ None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary Assignee: <praveen-sm.kumar@hp.com> Other Contributors: <shiva.kum.m@hp.com> <amank@hp.com> Work Items ---------- Highlevel tasks include: - Refactor the code of ChanceScheduler and LeastRouterSchedule. - This activity includes moving the common methods to the parent classes named BaseChanceScheduler, BaseWeightScheduler and inheriting those methods in ChanceScheduler and WeightScheduler classes. - Writing RouterFilter class and moving agents to routers binding logic there. Dependencies ============ Will reuse few methods from current scheduler classes. Testing ======= The code will be covered with unit tests. Tempest Tests ------------- None Functional Tests ---------------- Functional Tests will be added. API Tests --------- None Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ Scheduler section of OpenSatck Configuration Reference document needs to be modified. Developer Documentation ----------------------- None References ========== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/dhcpservice-loadbalancing https://review.openstack.org/#/c/111210/ https://review.openstack.org/#/c/137017/

commit_message:
neutron-ovs-dvr-multigateway

spec for https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/neutron-ovs-dvr-multigateway

Change-Id: Id33a343567a118bf91412d7f5b679118b54b36b3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/01/189801/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Neutron OVS DVR Multiple Gateway ========================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/neutron-ovs-dvr-multigateway For legary router, after creating a port from a router attached subnet and adding this port to another router as interface, we can manully update router routes to make previous subent can communicate with new attached router's subnets, this will not take too many handcrafter work and easy to under control. But for DVR router, it will be difficult to update distributed router's routes and maintain. We need especially support this for DVR routers. Problem Description =================== It should be necessary for router to attach a router attached subnet. Legacy router doesn't totally support this, for it's easy to implement by some handcrafter works and easy to maintain. But for DVR router, handcrafter works will hard to be done, and hard to maintain the extra routes for each distributed routers. Proposed Change =============== The following files will be modified to support extra routes updating and l3-agent notification for extra routes: * l3_dvr_db.py * (any other files if necessary) Some details: in l3_dvr_db.py * we will add logic in method add_router_interface to make sure extra routes can be insert into db and complete notification for all affected routers. * we will add logic in method remove_router_interface to make sure can be delete from db and complete notification for all affected routers. Image we have some network topology like this: ------------ ------------ -------- | router-1 | | router-2 | ----- | VM-3 | ------------ ------------ -------- / \ / sn3 / \ (port-A) / sn2 \ sn1 / sn4 -------- ---------- ------------ -------- | VM-2 | | VM-1 | --(port-B)--| router-3 | ---- | VM-4 | -------- ---------- ------------ -------- After DVR multiple gateway supported, we will need no more handcraft works to support VM-1 communicate with VM-3 on router-2 attached subnet sn3, or with VM-4 on router-3 attached subnet sn4, we only need create port port-A and port-B from sn1 and attach them onto router-2 and router-3. But we will not try to support VM-2 comunicate with VM-3 or VM-4 in this topology, so does VM-3 and VM-4. Alternatives ------------ For the attached port IP will be consider as gateway IP for extra routes, so maybe we could modify current router-interface-delete CLI, to make it possible to keep attached port IP, so when next time use router-interface-add to attach port as interface, the affected VMs will not need to update their route tables. Data model impact ----------------- Directly use current RouterRoutes table. REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <lzklibj> Other contributors: <vivekanandan-narasimhan, (need to discuss)> Work Items ---------- Need to discuss. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= For E-W traffic, affer attaching a port as interface to a router: * checking db or running related CLI to check whether extra routes are inserted into db. * using previous network topology as example, VM1 can ping VM3 or VM4, while VM2 cannot ping VM3 or VM4, and VM3 cannot ping VM4 or VM2. For E-W traffic, affer deleting a port interface from a router: * checking db or running related CLI to check whether extra routes are deleted from db. * using previous network topology as example, VM1 can ping VM3 or VM4 no longer. For N-S traffic, need to discuss. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None
