commit_message:
CLI implementation for listing and deleting tunnel endpoints

This specs introduces new CLI in neutron to list and delete
VXLAN/GRE tunnel endpoints.

Change-Id: Id1955008fee3e6aef1cd14eed3b512a864dfbcfc
Co-Authored-By: Romil Gupta <romilg@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Gandharva S <gandharva.s@hp.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/58/215058/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================================ CLI implementation for listing and deleting tunnel endpoints ============================================================ The idea of this proposal is to allow listing and deleting the VXLAN/GRE tunnel endpoints in Ml2. This proposal creates a new resource which will be used to fetch the tunnel endpoint details from the neutron server. Problem Description =================== We have a scenario where if we have a entry for (tunnel_ip, Host A) in ml2_vxlan/gre_endpoints tables for a given agent A. Consider that agent A goes down for some reason and never comes back. In case if we want to reuse the same tunnel_ip for agent B with Host B. The only option we have to delete the stale endpoint from the neutron DB manually which is not the feasible solution. Proposed change =============== To address the above problem the proposed change includes addition of new RESTful resources "vxlan-tunnel-endpoints" and "gre-tunnel-endpoints" to enable the retreival of VXLAN/GRE tunnel endpoint details supported by the ml2 plugin. By making RESTful GET call to the neutron-server, it retrieves the VXLAN/GRE tunnel endpoints associated with each agent/host. The REST calls made will retrieve this information from a table called ml2_vxlan_endpoints or ml2_gre_endpoints from neutron database. This blueprint will implement the CLIs which are provided to list and delete tunnel-endpoints. Listing and Deletion of tunnel endpoints is allowed only for admin user. Data Model Impact ----------------- NA REST API Impact --------------- List all VXLAN tunnel endpoints. Request :: GET /v2.0/vxlan-tunnel-endpoints Accept: application/json Response :: { "vxlan-tunnel-endpoints": [{ "host": "host1", "ip_address": "192.168.1.10", "udp_port": "4789"}, "host": "host2", "ip_address": "192.168.1.20", "udp_port": "4789"}] } List all GRE tunnel endpoints. Request :: GET /v2.0/gre-tunnel-endpoints Accept: application/json Response :: { "gre-tunnel-endpoints": [{ "host": "host3", "ip_address": "192.168.1.30"}, "host": "host4", "ip_address": "192.168.1.40"}] } Delete VXLAN tunnel endpoint for a specified ip address. Request :: DELETE /v2.0/vxlan-tunnel-endpoints/ip_address:192.168.1.10 Response :: Normal response codes: 201 Error response codes: badRequest (400), unauthorized (401) Delete GRE tunnel endpoint for a specified ip address. Request :: DELETE /v2.0/gre-tunnel-endpoints/ip_address:192.168.1.30 Response :: Normal response codes: 201 Error response codes: badRequest (400), unauthorized (401) Security Impact --------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- This change impacts neutron server and the python-neutronclient. Post implementation of this Blueprint, the user will see a new CLI under neutron. Performance Impact ------------------ None IPv6 Impact ----------- None Other Deployer Impact --------------------- None Developer Impact ---------------- None Community Impact ---------------- None Alternatives ------------ None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignees: * <neethi209> * <gandharva-s> Other contributors: * <romilg> Work Items ---------- 1. Creating New RESTful resources "vxlan-tunnel-endpoints" and "gre-tunnel-endpoints". 2. Add and implement the CLIs in python-neutronclient. Dependencies ============ Testing ======= Executing following CLI command displays all VXLAN tunnel endpoints. neutron vxlan-endpoints-list Executing following CLI command displays all GRE tunnel endpoints. neutron gre-endpoints-list Executing following CLI command with given ip address deletes the specified VXLAN tunnel-endpoint. neutron vxlan-endpoint-delete <ip_address> Executing following CLI command with given ip address deletes the specified GRE tunnel-endpoint. neutron gre-endpoint-delete <ip_address> Tempest Tests ------------- NA Functional Tests ---------------- NA API Tests --------- NA Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation will be updated to capture information about the new CLI. User Documentation ------------------ None Developer Documentation ----------------------- None References ==========

PBR version needs to be explicitly set on setup.py

the PBR version is not set in setup.py

commit_message:
Traffic direction for FWaaS

Specification for adding traffic direction (ingress/egress/birectional) for firewall policy rules in FWaaS.

Co-Authored-By: Vikram Choudhary <vikram.choudhary@huawei.com>

Change-Id: I6f4bfe585211da4bd24643778eb7150099319d05
Implements: blueprint fwaas-rules-directions
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/40/171340/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Specify direction for rules in fwaas ========================================== Problem Description =================== Currently in Firewall as a service implementation there is no possibility to set traffic direction for a rule and all rules are always set for both ingress and egress direction. It would be good to have posibility to apply rule only for one of those directions. Proposed Change =============== Add optional parameter to firewall rules to specify direction of rule. Rule with specified direction should be applied only in specified chain in firewall. Default value for direction parameter should be set to 'bidirectional' to have compatibility with old rules. Data Model Impact ----------------- In neutron's database in table 'firewall_rules' add new column: * 'direction' with possible values: 'ingress', 'egress' or 'null' (bidirectional) REST API Impact --------------- Add new optional parameter 'direction' for: * POST /fw/firewall_rules * PUT /fw/firewall_rules New parameter is described below: +----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+--------------+ |Attribute |Type |Access |Default |Validation/ |Description | |Name | | |Value |Conversion | | +==========+=======+=========+=========+============+==============+ |direction |string |RW, all |'' |'ingress', |direction of | | | | | |'egress', |traffic for | | | | | |'' |which rule | | | | | | |will be | | | | | | |applied | +----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+--------------+ Security Impact --------------- None Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ Probably none. In some cases there will be less rules in iptables set so then it can be littlebit better performance IPv6 Impact ----------- Should works with IPv6 same as with IPv4 Other Deployer Impact --------------------- None Developer Impact ---------------- Neutron client and Horizon should support passing and displaying new parameter in firewall rules. Community Impact ---------------- None Alternatives ------------ I didn't find any similar blueprint or proposal to firewall as a service. In Security Groups mechanism direction of rules is supported for now. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: slaweq Other contributors: vikschw Work Items ---------- API change to allow specify new rule's parameter DB change for add new column in firewall_rules table L3 agent firewall driver change for configure rules only in specified chain Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests will be added to test if rule with one/both/none direction is properly set in l3 agent Tempest Tests ------------- Tempest tests to check if rules with specified direction are applied on l3 agent's router should be added Functional Tests ---------------- None API Tests --------- None Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ Will require new documentation in fwaas add/update rule section Developer Documentation ----------------------- None References ==========

RST for blueprint security-groups-dropped-packets-event

APIImpact

Change-Id: Ie7be03acced5b77fff401c0d25a332749c22b710
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/84/169784/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ====================================== Security Groups Dropped Packets Events ====================================== Problem Description =================== The current implementation of security groups (using iptables) is not reporting packet drops in these scenarios: - Protecting against IP/MAC spoofing: i.e. connection attempts from another MAC/IP address. - Dropping all packets that do not match on an "allow" rule. Event report can help to detect miss-configuration, as well as provide data for external applications that do network activity analysis and threat detection. This blueprint proposes to add event report mechanism to the security group definition. Proposed Change =============== The proposed change is to add a Flag named "event" to a security group. This flag will toggle event reporting per security group. Security group instances with "event" flag set to "on" shall send events using ceilometer when packets are dropped. In addition, we propose to add a new security group configuration parameter named "firewall_event_max_rate" (format: number/unit, 10/minute for example) that will be used to limit the event generation rate. Proposed Change List: - Add column "event" to securitygroups table (see data model impact below), - Add the "event" parameter to the port information data that is passed to the firewall driver, - Add abstract class "FirewallEventDriver" using default ceilometer methods that publishes events on Ceilometer, - Add configuration parameter "firewall_event_driver" that specifies which concrete implementation class to instantiate, the implementation must extends the class "FirewallEventDriver", - Add a default no-op implementation "NoopFirewallEventDriver" that ignores events, - The proposed default implementation is an extension of the iptables firewall driver using syslog: - A LOG action is added on all iptables rules that enforce SG fall DROP and IP/MAC spoofing, resulting in syslog entries (when "event" flag is "on"). - In parallel, another thread in the "CeilometerFirewallEventDriver" shall parse syslog and publish the events on ceilometer - Add configuration parameter “firewall_event_driver_iptables_syslog” that specifies the destination syslog. By default, the value is "/var/log/syslog". Another case of events shall be added within the rate limit drop packet blueprint (see blueprint "security-group-brute-force-prevention") Data Model Impact ----------------- Add a new column "event" of type BOOLEAN (SMALLINT) to "securitygroups", which defines if packet DROP event reporting is requested on instances of this security group. +------------------------+----------------------+------------------------------------------------+ | Attribute | Type | Description | +========================+======================+================================================+ | event | Boolean() | On/Off Drop packet Events | +------------------------+----------------------+------------------------------------------------+ REST API Impact --------------- Add the following parameters to the Security Group "create/modify" API: +----------------+---------+--------+---------------+-----------------------+--------------------+ | Attribute Name | Type | Access | Default Value | Validation Conversion | Description | +================+=========+========+===============+=======================+====================+ | event | Integer | RW | false | boolean conversion | Flag on/Off Events | +----------------+---------+--------+---------------+-----------------------+--------------------+ Security Impact --------------- N/A. Notifications Impact -------------------- An extra notification is required: .. compound:: { "event_type": "security.groups.firewall.drop.packet", "time_stamp": "2013-04-07 22:56:30.026191", "message_id": 52232791371, "payload": { "message_id": 52232791371, "rule_type": "default drop rule | spoofing drop", "dst_port_id": "9803636f-03bd-4ada-8783-4946f758d384", "dst_ip": "10.0.0.29", "dst_port_number": 22, "protocol": "tcp", "src_ip": "10.0.0.25" } } Other End User Impact --------------------- There are changes required in python-neutronclient to support the proposed features. The user interface will be defined in another blueprint. Performance Impact ------------------ The event mechanism may increase CPU and local disk utilization on the compute Node. IPv6 Impact ----------- No change with the existing IPv6 infrastructure in Neutron. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- N/A Developer Impact ---------------- This blueprint contains only an implementation for iptables firewall driver based on syslog. However, other firewall implementations can implement it as well. The proposed changes in this blueprint have no other impact on developers. Community Impact ---------------- None Alternatives ------------ It is possible (through a much more complicated solution) to extend the security groups rules with "Event" rules that provide better granularity (i.e. log only the defined packets). Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Lionel Zerbib, Eran Gampel Work Items ---------- Dependencies ============ Testing ======= Tempest Tests ------------- Functional Tests ---------------- API Tests --------- Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ Developer Documentation ----------------------- References ==========

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-04-24 07:52:57.000000000', 'files': ['specs/liberty/agent-db-refactor.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs/commit/8e451bf390b354348516e06433b6683499c613c4', 'message': "Agent DB Refactor

For variant neutron agents, they share the same database model to store
basic information, configurations, as well as dynamic workload data.
Neutron-server depends on it to apply correct operations such as producing
API response, scheduling, and HA. Also, how to maintain, transport those
data is a performance factor to neutron. We believe the db model needs a
refactor, base on some thinkings of the two scenarios.

First, currently there is no attribute to identify agent logical status,
such as initializing, ready, data sync, or error. Once agent is connected
to neutron-server, only admin state and liveness is checked on server side.
That means neutron-server may apply operations on agent blindly.

Second, agents send heartbeat message to transport those data. However,
carrying/parsing static data and writing them to db everytime is
inefficient. We'd like to see static and dynamic data is well decoupled
in agent db model. Then agent only needs to send static data once, and

commit_message:
Agent DB Refactor

For variant neutron agents, they share the same database model to store
basic information, configurations, as well as dynamic workload data.
Neutron-server depends on it to apply correct operations such as producing
API response, scheduling, and HA. Also, how to maintain, transport those
data is a performance factor to neutron. We believe the db model needs a
refactor, base on some thinkings of the two scenarios.

First, currently there is no attribute to identify agent logical status,
such as initializing, ready, data sync, or error. Once agent is connected
to neutron-server, only admin state and liveness is checked on server side.
That means neutron-server may apply operations on agent blindly.

Second, agents send heartbeat message to transport those data. However,
carrying/parsing static data and writing them to db everytime is
inefficient. We'd like to see static and dynamic data is well decoupled
in agent db model. Then agent only needs to send static data once, and
subsequent heartbeats only carry dynamic data.

Change-Id: Ib7d50aa71ed2c482030ea48cd2ed4434fa5744a9
Blueprint: agent-db-refactor
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/08/177108/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================== Agent DB Refactor =================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/agent-db-refactor For variant neutron agents, they share the same database model to store basic information, configurations, as well as dynamic workload data. Neutron-server depends on it to apply correct operations such as producing API response, scheduling, and HA. Also, how to maintain, transport those data is a performance factor to neutron. We believe the db model needs a refactor, base on some thinkings of the two scenarios. First, currently there is no attribute to identify agent logical status, such as initializing, ready, data sync, or error. Once agent is connected to neutron-server, only admin state and liveness is checked on server side. That means neutron-server may apply operations on agent blindly. Second, agents send heartbeat message to transport those data. However, carrying/parsing static data and writing them to db everytime is inefficient. We'd like to see static and dynamic data is well decoupled in agent db model. Then agent only needs to send static data once, and subsequent heartbeats only carry dynamic data. Problem Description =================== * Lack of an attribute to identify agent logical status clearly: 1. Agent has different logical status, but existing db model only includes its admin state and liveness. Agent knows whether the initialization finishes, whether it's ready to accept tasks from server, whether a re-synchronizing happens so task should not be assigned during syncing, but server doesn't know. So neutron-server applies operations blindly; 2. Agents usually do a full sync after start up, which makes initializing period pretty long. A simple test shows that for DHCP agent, if there are 4k networks and 4k ports, the full sync will take more than 30 seconds in our OpenStack setup. But neutron-server considers this agent ready to accept new assigned workloads. For those new assigned workload, DHCP service is not setup till full sync finishes. VM may not get IP address; 3. Take DHCP and L3 agent as example, re-sync happens when some operations fail. At this point, neutron-server should not schedule new tasks to this agent, as explained above. But in existing implementation, new tasks may still be assigned; 4. There might be unrecoverable failure happened on agent. While "admin state" and "is_active" is still true, scheduler considers it as an eligible one. But this agent faces logical error and cannot process new assigned tasks. This logical status needs to be identified not only for other internal modules, but also for users; * Static and dynamic data is not decoupled and properly processed: 1. Currently agents carry lots of information in heartbeat message. What kind of data are included in heartbeat? And is it necessary to carry all those data in every heartbeat? The answer is no. 2. For example, "agent_type", "host", "binary", these data are static, and in every heartbeat, they are always the same since agents boot up. And on server side, they are parsed everytime. It's inefficient. Only the first heartbeat should take these static data; 3. For "configurations", there are both static and dynamic data in it. Take DHCP agent as example, "use_namespaces" and "dhcp_driver" are static, while workload information such as "networks", "subnets" and "ports" are dynamic. Static and dynamic data in "configurations" should be decoupled. Subsequent heartbeats only take dynamic data; Proposed Change =============== * Add new attribute to agent db model to identify agent logical status clearly. Attribute "agent_status" will be added. Agents is able to determine its logical status, maintaining a local variable and populating it into heartbeat; * State transition in agent side: 1. When agents boot up, "INITIAL"; 2. After data synchronization, ready to accept tasks, "READY"; 3. Re-sync due to task failure, "SYNC"; 4. After re-sync, "READY"; 5. Some internal error happens, not able to process task from server, but heartbeat is normal. "ERROR"; * For neutron-server, besides checking "admin state" and "is_active", agent logical status is considered and only assign tasks to agents in "READY" state; * Decouple static and dynamic data in heartbeat. For example, keep static data in "configurations", while move dynamic statistic information into a new attribute "statistics"; * Agents send all static and dynamic data during boot up. In subsequent heartbeats, only dynamic data such as "statistics" is needed; Data Model Impact ----------------- * Original agent db model is: mysql> describe agents; +---------------------+---------------+------+-----+---------+-------+ | Field | Type | Null | Key | Default | Extra | +---------------------+---------------+------+-----+---------+-------+ | id | varchar(36) | NO | PRI | NULL | | | agent_type | varchar(255) | NO | MUL | NULL | | | binary | varchar(255) | NO | | NULL | | | topic | varchar(255) | NO | | NULL | | | host | varchar(255) | NO | | NULL | | | admin_state_up | tinyint(1) | NO | | 1 | | | created_at | datetime | NO | | NULL | | | started_at | datetime | NO | | NULL | | | heartbeat_timestamp | datetime | NO | | NULL | | | description | varchar(255) | YES | | NULL | | | configurations | varchar(4095) | NO | | NULL | | | load | int(11) | NO | | 0 | | +---------------------+---------------+------+-----+---------+-------+ 12 rows in set (0.00 sec) * Field "agent_status" is added to determine agent logical status: +---------------------+---------------+------+-----+---------+-------+ | Field | Type | Null | Key | Default | Extra | +---------------------+---------------+------+-----+---------+-------+ | agent_status | varchar(255) | NO | | NULL | | +---------------------+---------------+------+-----+---------+-------+ * Possible value of agent_status is: 1. INITIAL 2. READY 3. SYNC 4. ERROR * Decouple static and dynamic data. Keep "configurations", but it only stores static data that never change after agent boot up. Move its dynamic data into "statistics"; * Field "statistics" is added to store dynamic data such as workload, resource usage, etc; +---------------------+---------------+------+-----+---------+-------+ | Field | Type | Null | Key | Default | Extra | +---------------------+---------------+------+-----+---------+-------+ | statistics | varchar(4096) | NO | | NULL | | +---------------------+---------------+------+-----+---------+-------+ REST API Impact --------------- For agent extension API, data carried by response will change according to model update. Security Impact --------------- None. Notifications Impact -------------------- None. Other End User Impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ Unnecessary data is not carried by heartbeat message anymore. So it reduces the transportation workload of both sides. Neutron-server doesn't need to do extra parse or write those static data into db everytime. IPv6 Impact ----------- None. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- None. Developer Impact ---------------- * Developers could use "agent_status" attributed to determine agent logical status, and apply appropriate operations on server side; * Dynamic data in "configurations" is moved out, and stored in a new attributed "statistics"; * For agent development, heartbeat should carry only the necessary dynamic data after start up; Community Impact ---------------- Will fully discuss with community to do it in a way that does not increase community maintenance or burden. Alternatives ------------ Keep existing implementation. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Robin Wang (launchpad-id: robinwang) Work Items ---------- * Agent db model refactoring; * Corresponding change in server side; * Agent logical status determination and report: 1. Start from DHCP agent; 2. L3 agent; 3. Other agents that needs to be updated; Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= Tempest Tests ------------- None. Functional Tests ---------------- Functional tests will be considered for this change. API Tests --------- None. Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ Update model change in user document. Developer Documentation ----------------------- Model change will be documented if necessary. References ========== None.

commit_message:
Agent Group and Pluggable Status Drivers

Proper operations in Neutron depends on agent monitoring information
and health status. Currently there is a heartbeat/DB based mechanism.
It is not instant, extremely inefficient and not scalable. And there
is no open framework to integrate other backends/mechanism.

For a lightweight, scalable and reliable agent status monitoring
and querying mechanism, we would like to see a membership framework,
to aggregate variant agents by type, provide internal services such as
membership registration/health status check/group member querying, etc.
And, it should come with pluggable backend drivers, such as DB,
zookeeper, memcached.

Change-Id: If4e52ffc665b6ede896342951920e3425d1cd69a
Blueprint: agent-group-and-status-drivers
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/21/168921/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================== Agent Group and Pluggable Status Drivers ============================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/agent-group-and-status-drivers Neutron needs to maintain up-to-date information of its variant agents, especially the health status of each agent, to apply proper operations on them and provide stable services to end users. For example, schedulers always make sure the agent is alive before assign tasks. HA periodically checks agent failure to decide whether trigger a recovery operation. Currently, this is done by agent heartbeat message, and DB persistence of heartbeat information. Agent periodically sends heartbeat message to neutron-server(by default every 30 seconds). Heartbeat timestamp and agent configuration information is parsed on server side and written into DB. When scheduler or HA needs to get agent status, those records should be retrieved from DB and compared with agent_down_time. Neutron server cost is not trivial and the cost increases when scale gets bigger. This mechanism is extremely inefficient and not scalable. A much more lightweight, scalable and reliable agent status monitoring and querying mechanism is desired for neutron. We would like to see a membership framework in neutron, to aggregate variant agents by type, provide internal services such as membership registration/health status check/group member querying, etc. And, it should come with pluggable backend drivers, such as DB, zookeeper, memcached. Nova used to have similar issue. See its problem descripiton and corresponding resolution at reference[1][2]. As reference[1] indicates that there was an agreement on design summit, oslo doens't provide this service as a common library, and each project should do it separately. Problem Description =================== Efficiency and scalability issue of current agent heartbeat reporting and health status checking mechanism: 1. Agents send heartbeat messages periodically, while neutron server needs to parse information and write into DB. Under large scale the cost is not trivial. To discover agent failure as soon as possible, we tend to configure "report_interval" smaller. But considering server workload, user must make a choice between instantaneity and stability. The default value is 30s in neutron configuration file. 2. To determine an agent failure, heartbeat record should be retrieved from DB. Timestamp of last heartbeat is checked to see whether it exceeds down time window. Again, when scheduler needs to check all agents status while making a scheduling decision, this cost is not trivial. 3. To make sure an agent is truly down, instead of a misinterpretation caused by message delay/loss, user should configure "agent_down_time" which must be longger than "report_interval". The default down time value is 75 seconds. DB based status check mechanism can not discover agent failure instantly. It might be 75s later when we know it's down. That is obviously a little longer. 4. HA is not timely. HA waits even longer time before triggering failover. For example, DHCP Agent HA uses a bigger time window, agent_dead_limit(150s) to determine an agent is down before applying recovery operations. Proposed Change =============== * Add AgentGroup internal API 1. provide membership registration, monitoring, health status querying, etc; 2. aggregate agents into groups by type, maintain membership for each group; 3. support fectching all alive agents at one API call, which is usefull for scheduler and HA; * Refactoring old DB-based implementation accroding to new API 1. New DB backend is in a drvier modality; 2. provide backward-compatibility; * Introduce new backend driver, start from ZooKeeper driver We expect to see more backend drivers in the furture, such as memcached; * (optional) refactoring HA mechanism, don't wait a long time before failover * (optional) replace periodical scanning into event trigger mode Data Model Impact ----------------- None. REST API Impact --------------- None. Security Impact --------------- None. Notifications Impact -------------------- None. Currently we will not change any existing notification mechanism. In the future, when use event trigger to replace periodical scanning, some notification changes may occur. Other End User Impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ * For DB-based backend driver, the performance would be similar with existing agent status monitoring/querying code; * For ZK-based backedn driver, a better performance should be gained: 1. Neutron Server doesn't need to use agent heartbeat message and its timestamp to determine agent liveness. So Agent doesn't need to set report_interval very small to get a better failure detection sensibility. User can set report_interval to a proper value, to let server get agent configuration/workload information. In that way, server burden for processing heartbeat and writing DB will decline. 2. When scheduler/HA tries to check agent liveness, it reduces server cost on DB querying and timestamp comparison, especially when check all agents. 3. No need to set a longger down_time(75s). Instant failure dectection. 4. HA and failover will be timely. IPv6 Impact ----------- None. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- 1. New config options will be introduced, for user to specify which backend driver to use. Default driver will be DB backend. 2. If use DB backend driver, there would be no difference for deployment. 3. If use ZooKeeper backend driver, a ZK cluster should be prepared. And new config options are introduced to specify ZK connection and other related information. Developer Impact ---------------- After internal API is introduced, new agent implementation, or new features that queries agent status, will use this new API. Community Impact ---------------- This allows admin/user to get an open framework for agent membership management, health status querying, and allow to introduce multiple different backends to achieve that. Will fully discuss with community to do it in a way that does not increase community maintenance or burden. Alternatives ------------ Keep existing implementation. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Robin Wang(launchpad-id: robinwang) Work Items ---------- * Add AgentGroup internal API * Refactoring old DB-based implementation accroding to new API * Introduce new backend driver, start from ZooKeeper driver * (optional) refactoring HA mechanism, don't wait a long time before failover * (optional) replace periodical scanning into event trigger mode Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= Tempest Tests ------------- None. Functional Tests ---------------- Functional tests will be considered for the new implementation. API Tests --------- Tests for new added interal API will be considered. Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ * New added config options * Deployment related information for new backend. Developer Documentation ----------------------- Document new added internal API and usage. References ========== [1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/NovaZooKeeperHeartbeat [2] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/zk-service-heartbeat

commit_message:
Add spec for port metering

Change-Id: I466844e76c90506e37bdb8b8b96c23c154a9743a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/33/190133/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============= Port Metering ============= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/port-metering This document describes a plan to add traffic counters for the ports. The traffic counters would be published by the notification api and could be consumed by Ceilometer. Each notification will send the port id, the network id, the device id and the device owner. Problem Description =================== Though now we have metering agent based on metering label, but there are still some scenarios it can't meet. Such as for the VMs directly plugged on provider network or when the traffic doesn't go through a virtual router. Proposed Change =============== 1. Add a new framework which will support different drivers, which will be placed under neutron/agent. The code path may be like below: ├── neutron │ ├── agent │ │ ├── port_metering │ │ │ ├── drivers │ │ │ │ ├── abstract_driver.py │ │ │ │ ├── __init__.py │ │ │ │ ├── noop_driver.py │ │ │ │ ├── ovs_driver.py │ │ │ ├── __init__.py │ │ │ ├── port_metering.py 2. For port_metering.py, it has some functions to handle the port change to maintain a local port list and a function will send traffic data regularly to message bus. 3. Changes added for agents, like ovs agent so that port_metering agent can be notified when there is any port change. Data Model Impact ----------------- None. REST API Impact --------------- None. Security Impact --------------- None. Notifications Impact -------------------- A new notification will be sent to Ceilometer. The format is as below: 'port_id' 'network_id' 'device_id' 'device_owner' 'tenant_id' 'bytes_tx' 'packets_tx' 'bytes_rx' 'packets_rx' 'time' 'first_update' 'last_update' 'host' Other End User Impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. IPv6 Impact ----------- None. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- Deployer need to enable this feature by adding new config: enable_port_metering = True in neutron.conf Developer Impact ---------------- Developer can add more drivers to collect the traffic of port. Community Impact ---------------- None. Alternatives ------------ Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: flwang (Feilong Wang, https://launchpad.net/~flwang) Other contributors: **TBD** Work Items ---------- 1. Define a pluggable framework to fit different drivers 2. Implement a reference driver for OVS Dependencies ============ Testing ======= Tempest Tests ------------- Tempest test case could be added to make sure the notifications sent from Neutron can be received by Ceilometer. Functional Tests ---------------- Functional test case will be added so that to make sure the notification is sent. API Tests --------- None. Documentation Impact ==================== Minor document changes will be required to reflect the configuration of enabling port metering. User Documentation ------------------ Admin guide will be updated to reflect the change. Developer Documentation ----------------------- None References ==========

commit_message:
ML3 router: reference driver/agent for routervm

This blueprint proposes reference driver/agent for routervm.  Its goal
is consolidate independent L3-plugins for routervm by implementing
reference L3 router driver/agents.

Change-Id: I4017fde3f07abacd09f442148fdb9489e4023987
Blueprint: l3-plugin-for-routervm
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/45/183145/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================ Modular L3 router plugin/L3 plugin for router VM ================================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/l3-plugin-for-routervm This blueprint proposes a reference driver/agent for modular-l3-router-plugin [ml3-router-plugin]_ for router VM. The resulted plugin will be used by router VM implementation. Problem Description =================== There are requirements to support Neutron's routing service implemented within VM instance. There are the existing l3 plugins and further proposals for it. [cisco-router]_ [vyatta-router]_ [netconf-router]_. Some has been merged into the Neutron upstream, some are still being proposed and more will come. The spec proposes a reference implementation for routervm and deserves common code base for code consolidation. Proposed Change =============== Implement a new driver/agents for modular l3 router plugin for router VM and introduce common library code for routervm management. And implement reference opensource implementation which uses Linux guest and guest agent. The following block diagram shows its architecture. The communication between l3-plugin and router VM is driver specific. The goal of this blueprint is to produce commonly usable l3 plugin that accommodate multiple drivers. As a reference implementation, guest agent will be implemented to run in VM. L3-agent will communicate with neutron server over provider network. A reference VM image would be provided for those who want to test this. As the first step, VM scheduling relies on Nova schedule and which router type is used is specified in config file. block diagram:: +------------------------------+ | Neutron Server | | | | +-------------------------+ | | | L3 plugin for router VM | | | | +-----------------+ | | | | |reference driver | | | +--+-+--+------------+-+-----+-+ | | | | REST API | | | V | +--------+ | | NOVA | | | server | | +---+----+ V | +-----------+ | | router VM |<----+ VM spin up/down +-----------+ Reference implementation:: +------------------------------+ | Neutron Server | | | | +-------------------------+ | | | L3 plugin for router VM | | | | +----------------+ | | | | |refernce driver | | | +--+-+--+-------------+------+-+ | | +----+ |amqp| +----+ | | +--------------------+ |config agent | | | | +----------------+ | | |router | | | |service handler | | | +----------------+ | | |reference | | | |driver for | | | |guest agent | | | +--+-------------+ | | | | +----+---------------+ | | provider | network | (This implies some interconnect between management | and provider network) | +--+-+-------+-+ | | | | +-+-------+ | | |reference| | | |guest | | | |agent | | | +---------+ | | | | reference | | router VM | +--------------+ In the above diagram, routervm is connected to openstack management network over provider network. Neutron provider network needs to be configured by the cloud admin. The details depends on each routervm implementation. Future plan For the record and the help to understand, here is the future plan. Those are out of scope of this blueprint and will be considered/addressed by future or other blueprints. The followings are good candidate for future plan with other blueprints. (random order) * support other services like firewall. * Hopefully deprecated the current existing l3 plugins. This requires the community consensus and deprecation process. future architecture diagram:: l3 plugin +-----------------+ | common logic | | l3_db/plugin | +-----------------+ / | \ l3 plugin driver interface / | \ +---------+ +---------+ +--------+ |reference| |routervm | |routervm| |driver | |reference| |driver | | | |driver | | | +-----+---+ +--------++ +-+------+ | | | -----------+------------------+--------+------------ agent | | | +--+---------+ ++--------+--+ | l3 agent | |config agent| +-----+------+ +---+--------+ | | +-+------------------+-----+ |agent common logic | |handlers of agent notifier| |polling | +-+----------+-----------+-+ | | | |agent driver interface| | | | +--------++ +----+----+ +-+------+ |l3 router| |routervm | |routervm| |driver | |reference| |driver | +---------+ |driver | +--------+ +---------+ | | | | | ------------------------+--------------+------------ instance VM | | V V +----------------+ +--------+ |guest agent | |routervm| |reference driver| +--------+ |(netns) | +----------------+ Data Model Impact ----------------- No modification to the existing tables are planned. The models defined in neutron.plugins.cisco.db.l3.l3_models will be generalized and moved into generic place. neutron.plugins.cisco.db.l3.l3_models and the related code will remain as is. The following is code snippet which is under development. :: class HostedHostingPortBinding(model_base.BASEV2): """Represents binding of logical resource's port to its hosting port.""" # id of given resource. e.g. router_id logical_resource_id = sa.Column(sa.String(36), primary_key=True) logical_port_id = sa.Column(sa.String(36), sa.ForeignKey('ports.id', ondelete="CASCADE"), primary_key=True) logical_port = orm.relationship( models_v2.Port, primaryjoin='Port.id==HostedHostingPortBinding.logical_port_id', backref=orm.backref('hosting_info', cascade='all', uselist=False)) hosting_port_id = sa.Column(sa.String(36), sa.ForeignKey('ports.id', ondelete='CASCADE')) hosting_port = orm.relationship( models_v2.Port, primaryjoin='Port.id==HostedHostingPortBinding.hosting_port_id') # NetworkSegmentation in hosting port # See plugin.ml2.models.NetworkSegement network_type = sa.Column(sa.String(32), nullable=False) segmentation_id = sa.Column(sa.Integer, autoincrement=False) class HostingDeviceAgentBinding(model_base.BASEV2): """Represents binding between hosting devices and config agents.""" hosting_device_id = sa.Column(sa.String(36), primary_key=True) # complementary id to enable identification of associated Neutron resources # when creating port before device creation, hosting_device_id isn't # available. complementary_id = sa.Column(sa.String(36)) mgmt_port_id = sa.Column(sa.String(36), unique=True) # id of config agent for this hosting device, None/NULL if unscheduled. agent_id = sa.Column(sa.String(36), sa.ForeignKey('agents.id'), nullable=True) agent = orm.relationship(agents_db.Agent) # If 'auto_schedule' is True then router is automatically scheduled # if it lacks a hosting device or its hosting device fails. auto_schedule = sa.Column(sa.Boolean, default=True, nullable=False) class ResourceHostingDeviceBinding(model_base.BASEV2): """Represents binding between resources and their hosting devices.""" # 'L3_ROUTER_NAT', 'FIREWALL', ... # neutron.plugin.constants.{LOADBLANCER, FIREWALL, VPN, L3_ROUTER_NAT} resource_type = sa.Column(sa.String(255), nullable=False) reousrce_id = sa.Column(sa.String(36), primary_key=True) # If 'auto_schedule' is True then resource is automatically scheduled # if it lacks a hosting device or its hosting device fails. auto_schedule = sa.Column(sa.Boolean, default=True, nullable=False) # id of hosting device hosting this router, None/NULL if unscheduled. hosting_device_id = sa.Column( sa.String(36), sa.ForeignKey('hostingdeviceagentbinding.hosting_device_id'), nullable=True) agent_binding = orm.relationship(HostingDeviceAgentBinding) status = sa.Column(sa.String(255), nullable=False) REST API Impact --------------- No special modification to l3 router api is planned. When flavor framework is supported by Neutron, l3 router api will be enhanced so that user can specify router type to be created. Security Impact --------------- None Notifications Impact -------------------- L3 agent notification will include device specific information. Other End User Impact --------------------- None as neutron router is managed by cloud admin. Performance Impact ------------------ Communication between neutron server and router VM may cause performance impact. This is not new thing with new l3-plugin. IPv6 Impact ----------- None Other Deployer Impact --------------------- The plugin needs to be set up and service VM server needs to be run. The details documentations will come. Developer Impact ---------------- Except developers who are interested in router VM, there is no other developer impact because only independent l3-plugin will be introduced. Community Impact ---------------- Alternatives ------------ None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Zang Rui Yalei Wang Isaku Yamahata(yamahata) Other contributors: Stephen Wong Bob Melander Karthik Natarajan vikram.choudhary Gal Sagie Work Items ---------- * clean up/refactor the existing l3 plugin/agent code ** split out device specific code from l3-plugin/agent * implement reference driver for the ML3 router plugin * implement reference router driver for config agent * implement l3 guest agent * implement necessary helper library ** clean up/refactor the existing csr1kv code(device handling, plugging driver and config agent), and make it generic. * create reference VM image * devstack/unit tests * tempest Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Necessary tests(tempest, functional) will be added. Tempest Tests ------------- Necessary Tempest tests will be added Functional Tests ---------------- Necessary functional tests will be added API Tests --------- None Documentation Impact ==================== new driver for ML3 router plugin needs to be documented. newly introduced configuration needs to be documented User Documentation ------------------ new driver for ML3 router plugin available to user will be added. Developer Documentation ----------------------- None References ========== .. [ml3-router-plugin] ML3 router plugin https://review.openstack.org/#/c/105078/ .. [cisco-router] Neutron routing service implemented using Cisco VM and physical devices https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/cisco-routing-service-vm .. [vyatta-router] L3 plugin for Brocade Vyatta vRouter https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/l3-plugin-brocade-vyatta-vrouter .. [netconf-router] Neutron host plug-in for Virtual Edge Firewall appliance with NETCONF interface for configuring policies https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/tcs-fwaas-netconf-host-plugin .. [router-type-aware-scheduler] Describes design of routertype aware router scheduler https://review.openstack.org/#/c/92004/ The followings are the links to related patches. .. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/124699 l3_db.py: factor out port creation/deletion/update logic for router vm .. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/116773/ WIP: router vm l3 plugin/driver/agent .. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/124699 l3_db.py: factor out port creation/deletion/update logic for router vm .. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/134997 l3 router: implements l3 routervm plugin .. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/134998/ l3 router: implements reference routervm(WIP)

commit_message:
ML2: convert security-group and address-pairs into extension driver

Create new extension drivers for security-group and extension driver, to
replace the legacy extension way. And refactor the process which verify the
potential conflict between drivers.

Change-Id: Ifa1212cb05654d613702fa0394a9fede92557fd8
Blueprint: ml2-extdriver-secgroup-addrpairs
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/23/169223/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================================== Convert security group and address pairs into ml2 extension driver ================================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/ml2-extdriver-secgroup-addrpair This spec proposes to convert security group and address pairs legacy extension to ML2 extension driver. Problem Description =================== That converting the security-group and address-pair into extension driver, not only make the code cleaner in plugin.py, but also could make extension driver to be the concentrated place to deal with the overlap between them with port-security. Because the port-security could only be set to False when no sec-group or address-pairs setting, and consider the loading order of extension driver, we can't simply only add the verification code in any one of the extension drivers, port-security, security-group, address-pairs. so we need build a new mechanism in extension driver to make the extension process could probe the conflict setting. Proposed Change =============== 1. Add corresponding extension driver file in neutron/plugins/ml2/extensions/, move the port dict operation into process_create/update_port ext driver method. 2. Add the verification code into one single extension driver, like port-security, and modify the extension manager to move the 'port-security' to be the last extended one. Then the verification code will verify the port dict which include the complete info. 3. Update devstack to add them as default configuration. (Not sure if we need make them configable) Data Model Impact ----------------- None. REST API Impact --------------- None. Security Impact --------------- None. Notifications Impact -------------------- None. Other End User Impact --------------------- Now the user need to add the configuration like 'security-group' and 'address-pairs' into 'extension_drivers' in ml2_conf.ini Performance Impact ------------------ None IPv6 Impact ----------- None Other Deployer Impact --------------------- None Developer Impact ---------------- None. We just use the current framework to convert the security-group and address-pairs. Community Impact ---------------- None Alternatives ------------ list the alternatives for probing the conflict: 1. Add the same verification code into every extension driver involved, then the conflict will be found at the first time when one of them loaded. But the same logic will be add 3 times in this example. 2. Do the extend processing in every driver normally, and add a new process after all driver extended to verify if there is a conflict setting. But the some time and rpc operation and resource created will be wasted, like create the address-pairs which will be discarded when the conflict be found finnally. Implementation ============== The function of security-group and address-pair will be implemented in extension driver framework. The 'TODO' code to check the setting with port-security in plugin.py will be removed. Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: * yalei-wang Other contributors: * yamahata (Isaku Yamahata) * rui-zang Work Items ---------- (name) means task assignment. * Convert security-group and address-pair into extension driver in ML2 (yalei-wang) * refine the processing code for the overlap with port-security (yalei-wang) * tests (yalei-wang) Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= reuse the current test cases for security-group and address-pairs. Tempest Tests ------------- None Functional Tests ---------------- None API Tests --------- reuse the current API test cases. Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ API and Admin guide will NOT be updated because it will change nothing. Developer Documentation ----------------------- None References ========== .. [ml2_extension_driver] Support for extensions in ML2 Mechanism Drivers * spec review: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/89208/ * etherpad: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/ML2_MD_extensions .. [ml2_extensions] Support for extensions in ML2 Mechanism Drivers https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/neutron-ml2-mechanismdriver-extensions .. [port_security_ml2] Add Port Security Implementation in ML2 Plugin https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/ml2-ovs-portsecurity * spec review https://review.openstack.org/#/c/99873/

commit_message:
Add route whose nexthop not in router's attaching subnets

Change-Id: If40b5379fee33d8cb05b63bf3dd39d99b30c7a90
Blueprint: route-nexthop-not-in-router-subnet
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/68/152768/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================================= Add route whose nexthop not in router's attaching subnets ========================================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/route-nexthop-not-in-router-subnet When adding extra routes to a router, the nexthop ip address must be in one of the router's attaching subnets, otherwise, neutron will raise a BadRequest error. This blueprint proposes to remove this restriction. Problem Description =================== An external network may have more than one subnets, but a router can only be associated with one gateway ip. In some scenarios, we would like a vm can communicate with subnets in the external network, which are not associated with the gateway ip. As the following graph shows, subnet 2 is connected to the router and provides the gateway ip. But we would like vm to communicate with subnet N. asciiflow:: +--------------------------------------+ | External Network | | | | +--------+ +--------+ +--------+ | | |subnet 1| |subnet 2| ... |subnet N| | | +--------+ +--+-----+ +---^----+ | | | | | +--------------------------------------+ | | | +-----------+ | | +--+---+--+ | router | +--+---^--+ | | +-+---+-+ | VM | +-------+ Thus we need to add a route to the router whose nexthop is in these none-gateway-ip-associated subnets. This operation can not be fulfilled currently because these subnets are not attached to the router. Neutron will reject this operation because the nexthop of the route is not in any of the router's attaching subnets. Proposed Change =============== Remove the restriction that nexthop of a route must be in one of the router's attaching subnets. Data Model Impact ----------------- None REST API Impact --------------- None Security Impact --------------- None Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None IPv6 Impact ----------- None Other Deployer Impact --------------------- None Developer Impact ---------------- None Community Impact ---------------- None Alternatives ------------ None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: caizhiyuan1@huawei.com Other contributors: TBD Work Items ---------- * Remove nexthop restriction * Add Test Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Tempest Tests ------------- N/A Functional Tests ---------------- Test route with nexthop not in router's attaching subnet can be added. API Tests --------- N/A Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ Inform user the restriction is removed. Developer Documentation ----------------------- None References ========== None

commit_message:
RST for blueprint security-group-brute-force-prevention

APIImpact

Change-Id: I602bf0183779f9d790d02b12c76ea63a663f6cdd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/47/151247/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ============================= Brute Force Threat Prevention ============================= Problem Description =================== Security Groups in neutron (e.g. East-West firewall) block by default all ingress ports. The egress/ingress traffic on ports of a Virtual Machine can be allowed by IPs or groups. However, when the ports are opened (i.e. “white-listed”), currently there are no security mechanisms to monitor the traffic on these ports. The high security risk scenario we want to enforce is internal attacks from a compromised server (VM). Up until now, this scenario went undetected. This blueprint introduces traffic **rate limits on these opened ports** to prevent a *brute-force* attack. These rules will only be available for ingress traffic. Proposed Change =============== The proposal here is to extend the functionality of the neutron security groups framework in order to protect East-West traffic from Brute Force attacks. Required extensions to the security groups module: 1) *New security group rules* including: - A rate limit: the threshold traffic rate beyond which the action is applied. The rate is calculated per source IP. - Fields to define which type of packets to count (existing matches + the proposed extensions) - An action: block the source for a certain amount of time or drop the packets beyond the threshold (i.e. first X packets per second are accepted and the rest are dropped) 2) The Security management capabilities (*REST API*) of the security groups rule definition are extended to take into account the new rule parameter definitions 3) The firewall driver implements the new security rules using iptables features 4) An additional blueprint will be submitted to the Horizon security management to support default templates for brute force prevention for popular services (e.g. rate limit new SSH connections to 5/s). Data Model Impact ----------------- The "securitygrouprules" table is extended to include the new security group rules: - The columns 'action'/'time' define the action of the rule: - DROP: drop the packets over the rate defined in the rule - BLOCK: block the source (IP) for 'time' seconds. - ALLOW: allow the flow - The columns 'rate'/'tcp_flags'/'state' are additional match fields defining the packets. The new columns are the following ones: +------------------------+----------------------+------------------------------------------------+ | Attribute | Type | Description | +========================+======================+================================================+ | rate | Integer() | number of packets per second threshold | +------------------------+----------------------+------------------------------------------------+ | tcp_flags | String(length=255) | tcp flags of the packet to count | +------------------------+----------------------+------------------------------------------------+ | state | String(length=255) | state of the packet | +------------------------+----------------------+------------------------------------------------+ | action | String(length=255) | allow, drop or block | +------------------------+----------------------+------------------------------------------------+ | time | Integer() | Time to block the source | +------------------------+----------------------+------------------------------------------------+ REST API Impact --------------- The Security Group Rule add API receives the following new parameters: +----------------+---------+--------+---------------+-----------------------+--------------------+ | Attribute Name | Type | Access | Default Value | Validation Conversion | Description | +================+=========+========+===============+=======================+====================+ | rate | Integer | RW | None | Only for drop, block | rate threshold | +----------------+---------+--------+---------------+-----------------------+--------------------+ | tcp_flags | String | RW | None | Only for drop, block | tcp flags packet | +----------------+---------+--------+---------------+-----------------------+--------------------+ | state | String | RW | None | Only for drop, block | packet state | +----------------+---------+--------+---------------+-----------------------+--------------------+ | action | String | RW | allow | drop, block or allow | allow, drop, block | +----------------+---------+--------+---------------+-----------------------+--------------------+ | time | Integer | RW | None | Only for drop, block | block time | +----------------+---------+--------+---------------+-----------------------+--------------------+ Security Impact --------------- N/A. Notifications Impact -------------------- N/A. Other End User Impact --------------------- The python-neutronclient must be changed to include the new security groups rules creation documentation parameters. The user interface will be defined in another blueprint. Performance Impact ------------------ The detection mechanism consumes a very little additional CPU and memory on the compute Node. IPv6 Impact ----------- No change with the existing IPv6 infrastructure in Neutron. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- N/A Developer Impact ---------------- This blueprint contains only an implementation for iptables firewall driver. However, other firewall implementations can implement it as well. The changes introduce here do not impact any of the existing functionality. Community Impact ---------------- None Alternatives ------------ The implementation may be done in the Firewall as a Service Module.However, the following benefits would be lost: - Second tier protection (Internal as well as external protection), - Single place to configure open ports along with their protection rules, this allows to make a simple UI for configuration purposes. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Lionel Zerbib, Eran Gampel Work Items ---------- Dependencies ============ Testing ======= Tempest Tests ------------- Functional Tests ---------------- API Tests --------- Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ Developer Documentation ----------------------- References ==========

commit_message:
LBaaS: implements LVS driver

This commit adds an LVS loadbalancer driver using keepalived.
The loadbalancer is going to use LVS-DR forwarding.

Implements bp/lbaas-lvs-driver

Change-Id: I6a0880e471ded7c0dd39d887ed2ea3352c263ad9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/48/209448/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ========================= Implement LBaaS using LVS ========================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/lbaas-lvs-driver This BP is a plan to implement the LVS LBaaS driver. LVS (Linux Virtual Server) is an in-kernel implementation of a loadbalancer. It is going to implement with LVS using LVS-DR forwarding. Problem Description =================== LVS is an open-source implementation and has a different set of features than the other open-source implementation, HAProxy. LVS offers UDP load balancing and source IP address transparency. It is desirable to offer an alternative choice to users. Proposed Change =============== Based on LVS-DR forwarding, it work as well as HAProxy and have a little change. It consists of a loadbalancer plugin driver and an LBaaS agent RPC implementation. The plugin driver implement all current lbaas apis including the management of pool, member and listener and so on. On the agent side, it consists lvs agent dirver. It is used to create lbaas namaspace and apply ipvs rule. When a loadbalancer and its pool members are created, some corresponding ipvs rule will be applyed in this loadbalancer's namespace. It will create a port attach to the same subnet as the pool. The common LBaaS code will have a minimal change that handles the lvs dirver method. Alternatives ------------ The alternative is to make this depend on the BP lbaas-support-routed-service-insertion, which was proposed for liberty. In order to compatible with original lbaas architecture and code, the configure of lbaas dirver is needed in nrutron.conf. General user will not sense the change between haproxy and lvs. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- The LVS driver should be almost as secure as the HAProxy driver, with the following exceptions. * Possible bug in the neutron-lb-member-status-update python code, which is kicked from keepalived processes. * Possible bug in keepalived or the in-kernel LVS implementation. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ For the existing HAProxy driver, at most one extra DB lookup per RPC callback happens. For the LVS driver itself, its performance impact is almost same as the HAProxy driver. Other deployer impact --------------------- None if a deployer doesn't enable the LVS driver. To enable the LVS driver, a deployer needs to: * Add a service_provider line in the neutron.conf pointing to the LVS plugin. * Install keepalived. * Install ipvsadm Developer impact ---------------- This proposal has been modified not to affect ongoing LBaaS rework. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: yaowei Other contributors: <launchpad-id or None> Work Items ---------- * Implement a loadbalancer plugin driver * Implement an LVS LBaaS agent driver using LVS-DR forwarding Dependencies ============ It requires the keepalived package, which is available both in Ubuntu and Fedora. Both l3-agent and vpn-agent will have LVS agent functionality. There should be no impact if LBaaS LVS isn't used, but to explicitly disable the LVS functionality, BP l3-agent-consolidation is needed. Testing ======= Tests will be done by 3rd party testing. devstack needs a change to be able to use this driver. Documentation Impact ==================== The Installation Guide and the Cloud Admin Guide needs setup and usage info. References ========== keepalived(8) ipvsadm(8) The LVS homepage (http://www.linuxvirtualserver.org/)

commit_message:
Filter core resoruces based on extended attributes.

https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1405057

Currently we can't filter core neutron resources(Network, Subnet, Port) based
on extended attributes.

Adding a generic framework that will enable cloud user to filter resources
based on extendend attributes also.

Change-Id: I75e813ea2e1385d5da3d01cfee7175a3aaa44aae
Co-Authored-By: Shivakumar M <shiva.kum.m@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Saro Chandra Bhooshan <bhooshan@hp.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/33/221233/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================== Filter resource list based on extended attributes. ================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/filter-resource-extended-attributes Add framework to filter core neutron resources based on extended attributes. Problem Description =================== Currently we can't filter core neutron resources(Network, Subnet, Port) based on extended attributes. Without this feature, cloud user will not be able to get core resources only pertaining to specific extendend attribute. Example: Neutron resource 'Port' is having 'security_groups' as an extended attribute. We can't retrieve ports having only a specific security group applied. Proposed Change =============== Adding a generic framework that will enable cloud user to filter resources based on extendend attributes also. The changes involved are below, - Coming up with generic design to filter resources like network,subnet,port with provided extended attributes. - Changes to the CLI to accomodate new filter design. The changes will be mostly similar to 'filter(criteria)' design pattern of the object oriented programming. Example Class names which will be implemented are below. Class name: CriteriaNetwork Methods : meet_network_criteria() Class name: CriteriaSubnet Methods : meet_subnet_criteria() Class name: CriteriaPort Methods : meet_ports_criteria() Data Model Impact ----------------- None REST API Impact --------------- None Security Impact --------------- None. Notifications Impact -------------------- None. Other End User Impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. IPv6 Impact ----------- None. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- None. Developer Impact ---------------- None Community Impact ---------------- None. Alternatives ------------ None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary Assignee: <shiva.kum.m@hp.com> Other Contributors: <praveen-sm.kumar@hp.com> <bhooshan@hp.com> Work Items ---------- The work items include: 1. Implement resource filtering mechanism. 2. Implement python-neutronclient changes for CLI. Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= Tempest Tests ------------- Testing will be added to test filtering. Functional Tests ---------------- None API Tests --------- None Documentation Impact ==================== Admin guide will be updated to add this mechanism. User Documentation ------------------ None Developer Documentation ----------------------- None. References ========== https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1405057 https://review.openstack.org/#/c/180413/ https://review.openstack.org/#/c/138695/

commit_message:
Support external static dhcp

This blueprint try to support neutron using external static dhcp.

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/support-external-static-dhcp
Blueprint: support-external-static-dhcp

Change-Id: Id4a8771c185a18a88bceeaeb3844a29820a48c3e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/30/200930/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================= Support For Using External Static DHCP ============================================= Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/support-external-static-dhcp Currently, neutron allow creating port on external network and with disable dhcp on subnet, when booting instance. But for neutron doesn't totally support that yet, so we have to do some handcrafts like, updating port, updating security group on compute node, to make instance's networking work. This blueprint will try to work on this, to make sure instance's networking will work without additional handcrafts. Problem Description =================== Neutron allow creating port on external network when booting instance, and after adding security group rules for using external DHCP, instance can get IP from external DHCP server. And as a common case, subnet of external network should set enable_dhcp option as false. But currently, neutron will still try to generate IP for port in above case. So, it will be hard to guarantee that IP the instance leased is the same as the one in neutron database. And for that, two things will easily appear, 1) user cannot get correct instance IP by running command "nova list" or "neutron port-list", 2) security group "neutron-openvswi-s*" in iptables on compute node will get wrong. As workaround, after getting the corret IP, which one instance get from external DHCP, we can use command "neutron port-update" to update record in neutron database first, and then restart openvswitch agent on compute node hosting the instance. But it's not good user experience. Proposed Change =============== New methods/files will be added under neutron/agent/linux, to communicate with external DHCP server on getting IP. New methods using ip_lib, ovs_lib and dhclient will be used, and rootwrap configuration will be modified for dhclient. The way to get IP from external DHCP server by using ip_lib, ovs_lib and dhclient is, first create ip link veth pair, like qvb and qvo, set mac(generated by neutron db) to qvb, add qvo to ovs bridge br-ex on network node, then run dhclient for qvb. After getting response from external DHCP server, the IP on qvb is the one we try to get for above mac. The time interval between we running dhclient and instance running their dhcp client, is small in mostly smaller than lease time, so it's possile for external DHCP server to reserve that IP for instance. Then we will delete qvo from br-ex, and delete qvo and qvb, kill dhclient. In deleting instance/deleting port case, we will also do most operations mentioned above, but run dhclient with release option, to ensure instance's IP is released. Current method create_port and delete_port in db/db_base_plugin_v2.py will be modified. After generating mac for port, we will judge whether current case is using external DHCP(network is external and subnet is dhcp disabled) or not. If it is, new method will be invoked to get IP from external DHCP server. Currently, no plans for support assigning external DHCP server IP, so no new data model impact and api impact exist. But once we try to support that, we will need modify current api "subnet-create" to support assigning an external DHCP server IP when enable_dhcp option is disabled. And subnet data model will need add new attribute, like external_dhcp. No plans for dealing with multiple external DHCP servers case, if we try to, assigning external DHCP server IP should be supported. Data Model Impact ----------------- None REST API Impact --------------- None Security Impact --------------- Need add rootwrap configuration for using dhclient. Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ For we are planning to modify current create_port and delete_port method in db/db_base_plugin_v2.py, so new changing code will be called once these two methods called. Table Network will always be queried, to check whether current network is an external one. Table Subnet will be queried if network is external, to check whether current subnet is dhcp disabled. For deleting port case, table IPAllocation and Port will be queried, to get network id, subnet id, port IP, and port mac. IPv6 Impact ----------- No plans for IPv6 yet. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- For famous linux releases, no additional installation need for dhclient, but for others, we need confirm dhclient is installed. Developer Impact ---------------- None Community Impact ---------------- None Alternatives ------------ This blueprint fits case that neutron is not allowed to manage external DHCP server, if neutron is allowed, writing a new agent seems better. Using scapy to send and receive packets, will take no need to create temporary ip link device, but that will generate additional dependence. Directly run dhclient on an ip link device will not work on network node, we need add it onto ovs bridge. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <lzklibj> Other contributors: <None> Work Items ---------- None Dependencies ============ Depends on linux utils dhclient. Testing ======= Tempest Tests ------------- Suggset to run an additional dnsmasq process as external DHCP server, with options like dhcp-range and listen-address at least. After creating a port on external network, need compare whether IP record in neutron database equals to dnsmasq record. Functional Tests ---------------- None API Tests --------- None Documentation Impact ==================== None User Documentation ------------------ None Developer Documentation ----------------------- None References ========== None

To resolve this, we need to allow cloud administrators to set rules of default
security group.

Blueprint: default-rules-for-default-security-group

DocImpact

Change-Id: I2610b23c2bd6d2ba5ef9c4800b7e0615b47c46e6
